George Henry Corliss re-energized the American Industrial Revolution with his slick steam engine. Since James Watt invented the modern steam engine in Britain in the Revolutionary year of 1776, no one had done much to make it less of a coal hog and more reliable as a source of energy.
Some factories preferred water as cheap and dependable. Textile and iron mills distrusted engines because they could go out of control and do damage. Corliss solved these problems, starting in 1849.

"He dominated steam-engine technology in the second half of the 19th century," Charles Morris, author of "The Dawn of Innovation," told IBD. "His first engine patent addressed both fuel consumption and speed regulation as related problems. He marketed his engine by offering customers an option of a fixed price or a percentage of the fuel savings it achieved. Most chose the contingent price and ended up paying much more."
In addition to his firm's profit, Corliss had earned by 1870 — when his patent expired — royalties of $213,000, worth $3.5 million now.
Corliss (1817-88) was born in Easton, N.Y., near Vermont, the son of a physician.

At 14, after schooling, he worked as a general-store clerk. When the store wasn't busy, he showed mechanical aptitude, inventing a machine to stitch leather shoes, even though he wouldn't see the inside of a machine shop until he was 24.
Teen Titan
At 17, he organized builders to replace a bridge that had washed away.
In 1838, he opened his own general store in Greenwich, N.Y., which he operated for three years.
In 1839, he married Phebe Frost; they had a daughter and a son. Phebe would die in 1859; six years later, he would marry Emily Shaw, who was 18 years his junior.

In 1843, Corliss received a patent for a sewing machine, sold his store and moved his family to the manufacturing center Providence, R.I., hoping to find a sponsor to bankroll his perfecting the machine. Finding no interest, he joined the Fairbanks, Bancroft & Co. machine shop as a draftsman in 1844; within two years, he became a full partner.
Meanwhile, he solved problems with the stationary steam engine that could meet the demands of high-speed manufacturing — as opposed to the engine that was adequate to power steamboats.

In 1848, Corliss entered into a partnership with two investors, John Barstow and E.J. Nightingale, to form Corliss, Nightingale & Co. in Providence, and he made his first improved engine. He received his first patent for it the next year.

"Conventional steam engines used a slide valve that alternately admitted fresh steam into a chamber, causing a piston to move, then discharged the condensation," Morris said. "Corliss estimated that much of the engine's energy was consumed just reheating after the discharge. He separated the intake and discharge valves, which reduced coal consumption 30 to 50%."

Textile mills were especially concerned with conventional steam engine performance. Threads would often break, and if several looms went down at the same time, the surplus power would shift to the remaining looms, which were already running at high speed, and do them considerable damage.

"This didn't happen often, but when it did, it was very expensive to repair," said Morris. "Corliss invented a clever automatic variable cutoff valve that could tune power output to delicate shifts in demand or, in an emergency, stop an engine very quickly."

Corliss spent the rest of his life perfecting the engine, receiving 60 patents, according to Frederick Jaggi, president of the New England Wireless & Steam Museum in East Greenwich, R.I., which houses a working Corliss engine.
Corliss and his associates built a factory at the junction of Charles Street and a railroad line in Providence, and expanded it until it covered five acres with 1,000 workers.
It housed four locomotive turnstiles connected to two railroad spurs so that one train could come in to be loaded, then turn to move out while the next was loaded.

"He was the first American to practice extremely precise, ultraheavy, hand-crafted machine manufacture," said Morris. "Every part for every product was made in his own factory. Besides his engines, he made a wide range of heavy machinery and parts, like wheels and shaft casings. His plant could pour single castings up to 32 tons."
In 1856, he formed Corliss Steam Engine Co., with himself as president and his brother William as treasurer. Three years later, they began exporting to Scotland; Europeans became major customers.
True North
Corliss supplied the Union with machinery during the Civil War.
In 1861, he received a federal order to make a large ring on which a gun turret could revolve for the Monitor, a new type of ship that had a hull of iron.
His factory was one of the few that could cast the ring. He put aside all other work and had the plant run day and night to build it and ship it to New York, where it was placed on the Monitor.

In March 1862, the first combat took place between ironclad ships in the Battle of Hampton Roads. Setting it off, the Confederate navy's iron ram Virginia sank two wooden ships off Norfolk in an attempt to break the Union blockade.

A third, the Minnesota, had run aground, but it was dark, so the Virginia returned to port. The next morning, it went out to finish off the Minnesota, but the Monitor had arrived at night to protect it.
Over the next three hours, they slugged it out, doing only modest damage to each other.

While the blockade stayed in place, the battle turned out to be the war's most important naval engagement. It received global coverage and had an immediate impact, causing major navies to stop building wooden ships and shift to ironclads with the kind of heavy guns that the Monitor had, which could swivel to fire in any direction.
In 1867, two years after war's end, Corliss competed against 100 of the best steam engine makers at the International Exposition in Paris and won first prize.
Long-Distance Praise

One of his rivals, Scott Russell, the British designer of the huge Great Eastern steamship, described the Corliss engine: "A mechanism as beautiful as a human hand. It releases or retains its grasp on the feeding valve, and gives a greater or less dose of steam in a nice proportion to each varying want.... (It) everywhere tells of wise forethought, judicious proportions, sound execution and exquisite contrivance."

Three years later, Corliss received the Rumford Prize from the American Academy of Arts & Sciences. The 1870 presentation for making crucial improvements to steam power came a century after Watt received his first patent for a modern engine.
Also in 1870, Corliss' patent expired. Competitors leapt to copy his work, and their products became known as Corliss engines.
One of these knockoffs earned Corliss the Grand Diploma of Honor in 1873 at the Vienna Exposition, though he wasn't there.
In 1872, Corliss became Rhode Island's commissioner to the Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia.
It was the same year that America took the lead as the world's top industrial power, with much of its manufacturing run by his engines, according to Time magazine.
When the fair opened four years later, 10 million people from all over the world came to see its 30,000 exhibits. The center of attention was Machinery Hall, which covered 13 acres.

Powering all the hall's devices was the world's largest steam engine, with a shaft 352 feet long and a flywheel weighing 56 tons, which operated almost silently. Corliss paid the massive engine's $100,000 cost (equal to $2.3 million today) out of his own pocket.
Afterward, he sent the engine to Chicago's Pullman Car Works , where it powered multiple machines until 1910.
In the mid-1880s, Corliss closed his plant to turn it into an assembly-line operation, but he died at 72, before he could finish.
The firm was bought by International Power Co. in 1900, then American & British Manufacturing Co. five years later. In 1925, it was merged into Franklin Machine Co.

Tyson Foods (TSN), whose brands include Jimmy Dean, Hillshire Farm and Ball Park, said it is working toward ending the use of human antibiotics from its domestic broiler chickens by the end of Sept. 2017.
The move follows similar announcements from McDonald's (MCD) and Costco Wholesale (COST).

While the meat producer says it is confident that its meat and poultry products are safe, it has already taken steps toward cutting out antibiotics, including nixing antibiotic use in its broiler hatcheries and trimming human antibiotic use on broiler chickens by more than 80% since 2011. Broiler chickens are poultry raised for consumption.

"Given the progress we've already made reducing antibiotics in our broilers, we believe it's realistic to shoot for zero by the end of our 2017 fiscal year," said Tyson Foods CEO Donnie Smith in a statement.
"But we won't jeopardize animal well-being just to get there. We'll use the best available treatments to keep our chickens healthy, under veterinary supervision," he said.
The company said it will create working groups with independent farmers in its meat supply chain to address ways to cut human antibiotic use in cattle, hog and turkey farms.

In early March, McDonald's said that within the next two years it will use chickens raised only without human antibiotics. Costco told Reuters it is working toward eliminating shared-use antibiotics in animals.

Restaurants, food processors and retailers are trying to keep pace with a growing consumer desire for more natural food. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) on Monday said it has eliminated genetically modified food from its menu, fulfilling a Chipotle vow from earlier in the year. Chipotle has faced carnitas shortages this year as its seeks a pork supplier that meets its standards for animal treatment.
Shares of Tyson rose 1.1% to 39.32 in afternoon trading in the stock market today.
Its stock is closing back in on its 50-day line after breaking support in mid-April.
Tyson said its antibiotics decision will not materially affect its financial performance.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.
RELATED: Costco Eyes Sales Curbs Of Antibiotics-Treated Meat

Arthur Davidson and his best friend, William Harley, were tired of pedaling their bikes to a fishing hole near Milwaukee. They decided to try attaching a small engine, but this turned out to be harder than they expected. They brought in Arthur's brother Walter, a machinist, and two years later, in 1903, built a prototype. Another Davidson, brother Bill, worked…
Polaris Industries roared ahead of third-quarter earnings forecasts Wednesday as its reinvigorated Indian motorcycle line sped forward.
The all-terrain vehicle, snowmobile and motorcycle maker also raised full-year guidance. But investors were unimpressed; Polaris (PII) stock fell 3%.

"It's all about expectations," BMO Capital Markets analyst Gerrick Johnson said. "They have been a rock star since before the (Great Recession) ... and people like to look for nuggets so they can call a top."
A couple of "nuggets" came up in Polaris' earnings call, he said, citing "some capacity constraints and delay in shipping some motorcycles. And their retail growth has been decelerating."
Still, "Smart guys like me are doing checks and coming up with good news," Johnson said.
Polaris' earnings per share minus items climbed 26% to $2.06 on an 18% rise in revenue to $1.3 billion. Polaris has beaten earnings estimates for more than eight quarters in a row.
Wall Street expected EPS of $2.02 on revenue of $1.28 billion.
Bread-and-butter, off-road-vehicle sales rose 17% to $823.2 million, leading Medina, Minn.- based Polaris to raise its EPS outlook for the current year to $6.55 to $6.65 from $6.48 to $6.58.
"We garnered strong retail sales in all categories," CEO Scott Wine said in a statement about Q3, "even as we introduced more than 20 new off-road vehicles and motorcycles."
Motorcycle sales grew 28% to $63.3 million.
Motorcycle rival Harley-Davidson (HOG) also beat Q3 earnings views Tuesday, but EPS and revenue fell from a year earlier. Its stock slipped 1% Wednesday after surging 7% the day before.

For Polaris, "It was a very strong quarter," B. Riley & Co. analyst Jimmy Baker told IBD. "I think the brightest takeaway was market share gains continuing on side-by-side (off-road sport vehicles) and ATVs."
Baker sees the Indian motorcycles as a big opportunity. The renewed, 113-year-old Indian brand, which Polaris bought in 2011, competes with Harley.
"Consumers are responding well to having a choice," he said.
Polaris also makes Dagor, the M RZR line and other defense combat vehicles, and Feltl & Co. analyst Mark Smith sees that business growing.

"It's a smaller piece of their business, but it's a great opportunity for them," he said. "In defense spending now vs. six months ago, the outlook is better for smaller tactical products" like Polaris military vehicles.Polaris Industries roared ahead of third-quarter earnings forecasts Wednesday as its reinvigorated Indian motorcycle line sped forward.The all-terrain vehicle, snowmobile and motorcycle maker also raised full-year guidance. Harley-Davidson's (HOG) third-quarter earnings dropped 5.5% to 69 cents per share amid intense competition and lower sales.
But shares jumped in early Tuesday morning trading as it easily topped Wall Street consensus for 59 cents per share.

Revenue for the iconic motorcycle maker fell 4.2% to $1.13 billion, a bit under analysts projections for $1.14 billion. The company said it was a difficult comparison vs. the same quarter a year ago when sales ballooned.

Shipments were down, but demand was still solid. Globally, dealers sold 73,217 new Harley-Davidson motorcycles in Q3 compared with 70,517 motorcycles in the year-ago quarter. Retail sales at U.S. dealers rose 3.4%.

Harley faces pumped-up competition, including from snowmobile and ATV maker Polaris Industries (PII), which bought the 113-year old Indian motorcycle brand in 2011 and has revitalized it with new and improved Indians. Honda Motor (HMC) also has released well-reviewed bikes recently.

Harley-Davidson has lost share to rivals, but in a report earlier this month RBC Capital Markets upgraded it to outperform from sector perform, saying it expects the company to regain lost share in the coming year with new motorcycles.

Harley CEO Keith Wandell in a press statement said, "With the successful launch of the 2015 motorcycles in late August, including the return of the Road Glide models," which the company had dropped this year, "and the outstanding efforts of our dealers, third-quarter retail Harley-Davidson motorcycle sales topped the strong growth of the year-ago quarter."
The company stuck with its earlier forecast that it will ship 270,000 to 275,000 motorcycles worldwide this year, a 3.5% to 5.5% increase over the prior year.
Harley shares rose 5.8% to 61.79 in Tuesday morning trading in the stock market today.
Polaris, which is projected to see strong EPS and sales gains Wednesday and which is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, was up 1.4%.

Hog futures fell, capping the longest run of weekly declines in 17 months, on speculation that a deadly virus that boosted U.S. pork costs killed fewer pigs than estimated.

The price decline to a five-month low indicates lower costs for bacon and pork chops, which climbed to records this year. Hog futures in 2014 soared as much as 56% to an all-time high in March.Futures dropped for the fifth straight week and have slumped 26% from the record $1.33425 a pound on March 18. The spread of the porcine epidemic diarrhea virus may have killed as many as 8 million piglets. Analysts including Paul Beere of Prime Ag Consultants say the slaughter shortfall in August from a year earlier will be about half of estimates."More hogs than were previously expected were showing up at market," said Dan Vaught, an economist at Doane Advisory Services in St. Louis. "At this point, the industry is pretty firmly convinced there's never going to be another good day in the hog market."Hog futures for October settlement declined 0.9% to close at 99.325 cents at 1:12 p.m. on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Earlier, the price touched 97.5 cents, the lowest for a most-active contract since Feb 20.In July, 332 cases of PED were reported, the fewest since October and down from the peak of 1,228 in February, data published by the U.S. Department of Agriculture on July 31 show. More than 7,800 cases were reported since the outbreak began in 2013 and spread to 30 states.

If you think managing innovation crushes freethinking, think again. The opposite is true: The more you facilitate and streamline creativity, the faster good ideas can make it to market and earn cash.So says innovation expert Steve Uban, the chairman of the Standards Committee at the Product Development and Management Association. That trade group feels so strongly about innovative discipline that it has launched a standard to measure how effectively firms capitalize on their genius."Some people think innovation standard is sort of an oxymoron: You're not supposed to manage innovation; it's supposed to be free-flowing," Uban told IBD."But we can show, through the research that we do, that when you manage product and service innovation, you get better results."How much better? "You get a 90% better return on your investment if you use best practice tools," he estimated.The PDMA's International Innovation Management Standard provides benchmarks that executives can use to increase idea flow and product development at any firm. The standard, a result of the group's research into product development by heavyweights such as Harley-Davidson (HOG), DuPont (DD) and Clorox (CLX), is designed to help firms figure out the elements of high-impact innovation.Executives and innovative teams can measure themselves against the standard through a self-assessment or an audit from the PDMA.Adopt these characteristics to capitalize on ingenuity at your firm:• Inventive outlook. At crackerjack-thinking workplaces, ideas come naturally. But there's a strategy to it, Uban explains, and it's not just about buying trendy couches or glow-in-the-dark whiteboards.Think about how chiefs respond to bold thinking or react to flops, the occasional byproduct of sizzling brainstorms.• Patience. "If risk taking and making mistakes are treated harshly in a company, no matter what you do, you are going to have a cloud over the innovation process," Uban noted. "That will restrict how innovative (employees) are."• Increased idea volume. The most brilliant firms are constantly brewing their next best-seller. "How fully loaded is your innovation pipeline?" Uban asks.You should be stabbing at industry upheavals, he adds, along with tweaking today's top-selling items.• Crunch. You can boost innovation by giving workers the gift of time, Uban teaches, to let their minds wander and scan trends in other industries — to sketch, test and stretch. "You need to have long-range innovation along with short-term projects," he said. "It's like a balanced portfolio."• Creative connection. To develop good ideas, every department should embrace innovation.Consider hatching new goals to reward all employees for shepherding strong concepts. You can also retool your budget to reimburse divisions for the time they spend on innovation, Uban says.• Calculated criticism. Give leaders plenty of chances to question and probe potential breakthroughs. But think strategically about when to identify holes in an idea."You don't want leadership coming in at the end of a project and saying, 'No, this isn't right,'" Uban explained. "If they want input, they need to do that at the beginning, before the team gets started."• Mix and hatch. "One of the secrets I have found works is this cross-pollination of knowledge between design, engineering and marketing," said Robert Hale, PDMA's chairman. "The OCI (outstanding corporate innovator) award winners always talk about how they cross-pollinate."

You spend years in college learning and earning a business degree. Then you stay up-to-date with seminars, online classes and conferences. But Marsha Lindsay, CEO of Wisconsin-based communications firm Lindsay, Stone & Briggs, says you should spend as much time unlearning. Why?

"Concepts, research findings and cases 10-15 years old, given the dramatic changes in the world, are out of date," she told IBD. "Many of the current ideas of what it takes to grow a business are borne out of the '80s and '90s, when marketing was not practiced as a science, but based more on anecdotes. The louder practitioners would say this works for me, and what they said took on the status of truth."
Lindsay says data show that widely held beliefs about what helps a business grow should be challenged. Rethink conventional wisdom and use these strategies to boost your market share:

• Seek new leads. While it's crucial to deliver to your current customers, it's equally key to find new buyers. "The only way to grow a brand is to increase the number of people who use it," Lindsay said.

Some say it's cheaper to spend all your marketing dollars keeping existing clients than trying to find new customers. Lindsay disputes that point. "If you target existing customers and get them to buy more, it doesn't grow the size of your market share," she said.
If you already drink two Cokes a day, what are the chances you're going to drink three or four? Not high, Lindsay says.

• Create widespread value. Aim your products to appeal to a large audience. Don't count on a few rabid fans to increase your market share, says Byron Sharp, director of the Ehrenberg-Bass Institute for Marketing Science at the University of South Australia.

"Any brand can have a few fans," he wrote in "How Brands Grow." But that doesn't mean "fans are of any financial or strategic consequence to marketers. These make for an entertaining story and that's all. Advertising agencies, who in general know very little about buyer behavior, love these stories."

Harley-Davidson (HOG), he says, is the poster child for brand loyalty. Sharp points out that the tag did little to protect the motorcycle firm from losing market share to Japanese brands often cited as having better quality.

• Spend on advertising. Lindsay says firms should put resources toward advertising to increase market share. You want more new customers buying your product at full price. Price promotions don't get you a bigger piece of the pie.

"It's long been known that when a product is often promoted at discount, we train the customer to buy it only when it's discounted, further eroding profit margins," Lindsay said. "And just because they get a deal, people don't always go back and buy your product again; they might have just tried it because it was cheap."

• Analyze data correctly. People buy what they want and need on their own timeline. Your company shouldn't stock up while assuming that 20% of your customers give you 80% of your sales. Lindsay says data show that 50% of your business comes from 20% of your customers in the first year. The numbers become even less impressive as the years go on because people move on and try other products.
• Find commonality. People are more alike than different. "Brands sell to pretty much the same types of people and, in fact, the very same people," Lindsay said.

The conventional wisdom is that competing brands sell to different market segments. So you must spend tons of resources trying to figure out which slice you're going to chase.You spend years in college learning and earning a business degree. Then you stay up-to-date with seminars, online classes and conferences. But Marsha Lindsay, CEO of Wisconsin-based communications firm Lindsay, Stone & Briggs, says you should spend as much time unlearning. Hog futures rose to a record, joining this month's cattle rally to an all-time high, as supply concerns mounted amid a spreading virus that kills piglets and signs that U.S. pork output is declining.

Porcine epidemic virus, or PED, has killed more than 4 million pigs in the U.S., according to the National Pork Producers Council. As of Feb. 22, 16.3 million hogs were slaughtered in 2014, down 2.7% from a year earlier, government data show.Hogs have jumped 25% in 2014, the second-biggest gain among 24 raw materials in the Standard & Poor's GSCI Spot index. Demand for pork has increased as beef costs climbed. U.S. consumers will pay as much as 3.5% more for meat this year, compared with a 1.2% advance in 2013, the government has forecast.Hog futures for April settlement climbed 2.9% to close at $1.0685 a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, a record high, rising by the 3-cent exchange limit. Trading more than doubled compared with the 100-day average for this time, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.Global AgriTrends, a Denver-based research company, has said the PED virus may kill as many as 5 million pigs, or about 4.5% of the animals sent to processing plants last year in the U.S., the world's biggest pork exporter.On Thursday, hogs jumped 2.8%, the most since March 7, partly on speculation that demand for pork will increase as a cheaper alternative to beef.

Forget that Apple (AAPL) makes the bulk of its products in China. That didn't stop the company from debuting on a top-10 list of "Most Patriotic Brands." As marketers gear up for Fourth of July shoppers, brands will capitalize on all the red, white and blue they can.

American consumers saw stars — the star-spangled banner, that is — as they awarded Chrysler's Jeep, Levi Strauss and Coca-Cola (KO) the top three spots on the list, according to a study from brand-loyalty research firm Brand Keys. Newcomers included Apple (sharing No. 6 with Procter & Gamble's (PG) Gillette), Amazon (AMZN) (No. 8) and Google (GOOGL) (sharing the No. 10 spot with AT&T (T). The survey asked 4,680 Americans aged 16 to 65 to evaluate brands on 35 values, including patriotism.

Brand engagement is more emotional than rational, said Brand Keys founder and President Robert Passikoff, even if consumers know the difference between patriotism and the image of patriotism that some brands project.

"More importantly, believability is key to the engagement paradigm," he said. "The more engaged a consumer is with a particular emotional value and the associated brand, the more likely they'll trust that emotion and act positively on that belief."
Other iconically American brands were predictably on the list, including Ford Motor (F), Harley-Davidson Motor (HOG) and Walt Disney (DIS).
Along with Apple and Google, digital brands Facebook (FB) and eBay (EBAY) were other first-timers who made appearances at No. 16 and No. 22, respectively.

"Marketers like Independence Day because it gives them an opportunity to help citizens celebrate with patriotic flag-waving and red-white-and-blue motifs," said Passikoff. "Marketers cue the marching bands and majorettes, and look to leverage all the patriotic emotions that symbolize America. And for some, increased sales."Forget that Apple (AAPL) makes the bulk of its products in China. That didn't stop the company from debuting on a top-10 list of "Most Patriotic Brands." Soybeans jumped the most in five weeks on signs of higher demand for U.S. supplies from China, the world's top consumer of the oilseed used in livestock feed. Wheat rose on Egyptian purchases, and corn gained.

U.S. exporters sold 140,000 metric tons of soybeans to China for delivery by Aug. 31, the Department of Agriculture said Monday in a statement. Soybeans inspected for export last week rose 45% from a year earlier to 59.38 million bushels, with China accounting for 73%, the USDA said Monday. Imports from all sources by China, the top hog producer, jumped to a record 7.4 million tons last month.

"Chinese demand continues to support higher prices," said Sterling Smith, a futures specialist at Citigroup Global Markets. "Most people have been looking for a slowdown in Chinese buying of U.S. soybeans and a shift to cheaper Brazilian supplies."

Soybean futures for March delivery gained 1.2% to close at $12.9425 a bushel at 1:15 p.m. on the Chicago Board of Trade, the biggest gain since Dec. 9. Prices fell 8.3% in 2013 on forecasts for record harvests in South America beginning this month.
Wheat futures for March delivery climbed 0.8% to $5.735 a bushel, the first gain in six sessions. On Jan. 10, the price fell to $5.605, the lowest since July 2010.

Corn futures for March delivery rose 0.4% to $4.345 a bushel. The grain jumped 5% on Jan. 10 after the USDA said domestic production and reserves were smaller than forecast by analysts.Soybeans jumped the most in five weeks on signs of higher demand for U.S. supplies from China, the world's top consumer of the oilseed used in livestock feed. Harley-Davidson (HOG) rumbled past first-quarter analyst expectations, as the economy improved and younger riders embraced the iconic brand. Shares traded up 5% Wednesday afternoon following the earnings report.
The Milwaukee-based firm posted EPS of 74 cents, up 45% from a year ago and 2 cents above analyst forecasts. Net sales climbed 17% to $1.43 billion, ahead of analyst expectations for $1.22 billion.
The company sold 59,677 new Harleys globally in the quarter, up 20.3% from a year ago.
U.S. sales climbed 25.5% to 39,762. That outpaced the broader U.S. heavy motorcycle industry unit sales, which climbed 17.5% in the quarter, the company said.

"We continue to be encouraged by the strong trend at retail and in earnings over the past several quarters," CEO Keith Wandell said in a statement. "Our first-quarter performance reflects the outstanding appeal of our products, the ongoing results of our transformation strategy, the efforts of our dealers and employees, and improving macroeconomic conditions in the U.S."

The company said it expects to ship 79,000-84,000 motorcycles in the second quarter. For all of 2012, it increased its guidance range to 245,000-250,000 motorcycles worldwide, from earlier forecasts of 240,000-245,000 motorcycles.
Harley-Davidson, with an IBD Composite Rating of 95, cruises in the top-ranked Leisure-Products group.

The group includes Polaris (PII), an ATV maker that competes with Harley through its Victory and Indian motorcycle lines. That firm, with a best-possible 99 Composite Rating, last week handily beat analyst views, also citing that improving economy in the strong sales hike of its off-road vehicles.

The group also includes gun maker Sturm Ruger (RGR), also with a 99 Composite Rating. Ruger sales have soared in part on fears that lawmakers in Washington will initiate a new round of gun control legislation. Top communicators know there are as many ways to tell others about who you are as there are colors in a box of crayons. Want to slam-dunk your personal and corporate goals? Push past the use of words and gestures. Get your meaning across in new ways. How:

• Sniff. "When I'm in an international airport, I go into the duty free shop and I smell all of the latest fragrances," sensory awareness pioneer Gail Vance Civille told IBD. "I want to see what the trends are." Her Sensory Spectrum shows top brands how to reach people's eyes, ears, nose, mouth and skin. Perfumers know what makes shoppers tick on a primal level, she notes. Lemon lime fiends want brightness and clarity; vanilla spells warmth and coziness.
• Air it. Bad scents can kill business, Civille preaches.

How so? She often walks into restaurant foyers that reek of bathroom cleaner. Big blemish. Walk through your business and take a whiff. Ventilate, or lose repeat visitors. "Reroute the smell that's coming from the bathroom," she said.

• Go for guts. Handbag designer Matt Murphy, who founded his namesake firm, makes it a point: Package purses for shipping so a waft of rich leather rises on opening, and bonds customers to carryalls. "It's like a mother smelling her baby for the first time," he said. "It's a very visceral experience."
• Peer. Say you're hoping to up buy-in among big income earners. Take a peek at what hues other firms are using to draw them.

"Are the Ralph Lauren (RL) ads all showing greens and rusts?" Civille said. "If I am trying to reach a high-end audience, I am not going to do it with pastel pinks and yellow." Richer colors, such as those greens and rusts, might work better.
• Practice. In the kitchen, taste and compare spices, coffee and types of cheese. It will make you more sensory aware, Civille says.
• Make it sing. The most functional parts of your product can move people.
"We use Swiss zippers because they feel really good, and they sound really good," Murphy said. Swiss zippers have superior casting and a liquidlike slide, he says.
"You would think everyone wants a quiet car. But if you were selling a sports car, it has to have some vroom vroom," said Civille. "If it doesn't have vroom vroom, people think it's boring."
In the 1990s, she adds, Harley-Davidson (HOG) made a move to trademark its signature motor sound, caused by pistons firing at odd intervals. Why? The unique rumble of the bike wins customers.

• Tell with taste. Business owner and chef Grant Achatz knew he was asking investors to back a radical restaurant concept when he was planning Alinea in Chicago, his award-winning eatery. One tested menu item: postage stamp-size, distilled pizza on rice paper crust.
He grabbed venture capitalists by the buds, boxing his business plan with a tiny, five-course meal dried in labeled vials.
"We could've just sent an e-mail," he wrote in his book, "Life, On the Line: A Chef's Story of Chasing Greatness, Facing Death and Redefining the Way We Eat."
"But I think this shows that we are very serious about doing something different."

• Break out. An architect, Murphy saw in the '90s that people were building their lives around gadgets, not places. "My first collection was developed for the urban nomad," he said. "My idea was to have a portable architecture."

The rules of making a good building worked for purses, and now Murphy has branched into a line of well-balanced spices. Tip: Making a sensory statement can wow investors and consumers.Top communicators know there are as many ways to tell others about who you are as there are colors in a box of crayons. One tested menu item: postage stamp-size, distilled pizza on rice paper crust.He grabbed venture capitalists by the buds, boxing his business plan with a tiny, five-course meal dried in labeled vials."We could've just sent an e-mail," he wrote in his book, "Life, On the Line: A Chef's Story of Chasing Greatness, Facing Death and Redefining the Way We Eat.""But I think this shows that we are very serious about doing something different."• Break out. An architect, Murphy saw in the '90s that people were building their lives around gadgets, not places. "My first collection was developed for the urban nomad," he said. "My idea was to have a portable architecture."The rules of making a good building worked for purses, and now Murphy has branched into a line of well-balanced spices. Tip: Making a sensory statement can wow investors and consumers.

You spend years in college learning and earning a business degree. Then you stay up-to-date with seminars, online classes and conferences. But Marsha Lindsay, CEO of Wisconsin-based communications firm Lindsay, Stone & Briggs, says you should spend as much time unlearning. Why?

"Concepts, research findings and cases 10-15 years old, given the dramatic changes in the world, are out of date," she told IBD. "Many of the current ideas of what it takes to grow a business are borne out of the '80s and '90s, when marketing was not practiced as a science, but based more on anecdotes. The louder practitioners would say this works for me, and what they said took on the status of truth."
Lindsay says data show that widely held beliefs about what helps a business grow should be challenged. Rethink conventional wisdom and use these strategies to boost your market share:

• Seek new leads. While it's crucial to deliver to your current customers, it's equally key to find new buyers. "The only way to grow a brand is to increase the number of people who use it," Lindsay said.

Some say it's cheaper to spend all your marketing dollars keeping existing clients than trying to find new customers. Lindsay disputes that point. "If you target existing customers and get them to buy more, it doesn't grow the size of your market share," she said.
If you already drink two Cokes a day, what are the chances you're going to drink three or four? Not high, Lindsay says.

• Create widespread value. Aim your products to appeal to a large audience. Don't count on a few rabid fans to increase your market share, says Byron Sharp, director of the Ehrenberg-Bass Institute for Marketing Science at the University of South Australia.

"Any brand can have a few fans," he wrote in "How Brands Grow." But that doesn't mean "fans are of any financial or strategic consequence to marketers. These make for an entertaining story and that's all. Advertising agencies, who in general know very little about buyer behavior, love these stories."

Harley-Davidson (HOG), he says, is the poster child for brand loyalty. Sharp points out that the tag did little to protect the motorcycle firm from losing market share to Japanese brands often cited as having better quality.

• Spend on advertising. Lindsay says firms should put resources toward advertising to increase market share. You want more new customers buying your product at full price. Price promotions don't get you a bigger piece of the pie.

"It's long been known that when a product is often promoted at discount, we train the customer to buy it only when it's discounted, further eroding profit margins," Lindsay said. "And just because they get a deal, people don't always go back and buy your product again; they might have just tried it because it was cheap."

• Analyze data correctly. People buy what they want and need on their own timeline. Your company shouldn't stock up while assuming that 20% of your customers give you 80% of your sales. Lindsay says data show that 50% of your business comes from 20% of your customers in the first year. The numbers become even less impressive as the years go on because people move on and try other products.
• Find commonality. People are more alike than different. "Brands sell to pretty much the same types of people and, in fact, the very same people," Lindsay said.

The conventional wisdom is that competing brands sell to different market segments. So you must spend tons of resources trying to figure out which slice you're going to chase.You spend years in college learning and earning a business degree. Then you stay up-to-date with seminars, online classes and conferences. Harley-Davidson (HOG) said third-quarter profit fell Tuesday as it revamped production at its largest plant. But in spite of a drop in production, the iconic motorcycle maker still beat estimates, sending shares up.

Harley said Q3 EPS fell 24.4% to 59 cents, beating estimates by a penny. The company implemented an enterprise resource planning system at its largest factory in York, Pa., reducing the number of motorcycle shipments during the quarter. Sales fell 11.6% to $1.09 billion, under estimates of $1.12 billion. Shares rose 6.5% to 46.38.
The new production system is expected to help raise efficiency and is slated to be ready for an increase in seasonal production next year.
While the improvements to the Harley plant will boost production in upcoming quarters, it hurt sales during Q3.

"We believe our U.S. dealers' third-quarter new motorcycle sales were adversely affected by a limited availability of new motorcycles in July, August and early September resulting from the ERP implementation at York combined with the move of Harley-Davidson's annual new model launch to late August from late July," CEO Keith Wandell said.

Motorcycle revenue fell 16.1% during the quarter. Harley shipped 52,793 motorcycles to dealers and distributors during the quarter,a 14.5% dip vs. 2011. Gross margin widened to 34.7% from 33.7% in last year's Q3.
Dealers sold 61,053 new Harley-Davidson motorcycles globally, down from 61,838 motorcycles in Q3 2011.
Harley-Davidson expects to ship 245,000 to 250,000 motorcycles to dealers in 2012, a 5%-7% decrease from 2011.

Last Thursday Polaris (PII), the maker of all-terrain vehicles, motorcycles and snowmobiles, reported a 40% jump in EPS and a 21% jump in quarterly revenue. The company raised its full-year EPS and sales targets for the third time this year. Shares fell 0.7% to 84.85.

Sturm Ruger (RGR) is slated to report quarterly earnings on Wednesday, Oct. 31. The gunmaker's EPS is expected to climb 43% to 80 cents and sales are seen up 39% to $112.1 million. Shares fell 0.8% to 46.37.

Cabela's (CAB) is expected to announce third-quarter results on Thursday. The hunting, fishing and outdoor equipment store operator is expected to report a 22% rise in earnings to 61 cents per share. Revenue is expected to rise 10.9% to $752.77 million. Shares fell 1.3% to 54.33.Harley-Davidson (HOG) said third-quarter profit fell Tuesday as it revamped production at its largest plant. In the late 1970s, John Allison was an account manager at regional bank BB&T. At the time, BB&T was engaged primarily in farm lending.

"I was financing a large hog producer," recalled Allison, who was BB&T's chairman and chief executive from 1989 to 2008. "The owner of the farm walks into my office at 4 p.m., slams a big wad of keys on my desk and says, 'The hogs eat at 5.'"

Allison rushed to the hog operation and found the farmhand in charge of feeding its 10,000 pigs. The farmhand refused unless he got paid. Allison wrote him a personal check on the spot, thus saving the farm but teaching the future bank leader a valuable lesson.

"I knew there was a character issue with this owner," Allison said. "There were several instances that pointed to a pattern that led me to see he had a character flaw. But I ignored his questionable behavior."
A 30-Year Lesson
Looking back, Allison wishes he had denied the farm owner's loan request. But times were good and Allison knew "you tend to make a lot of money in the hog business when prices rise."
Allison acknowledges that rejecting the farm owner's business would have hurt the bank's earnings in the short run. But long-term headaches ultimately outweighed any quick profit on the account.
Nearly 30 years later, Allison prevented BB&T from getting caught up in negative amortization mortgages. He correctly predicted that these products would prove faulty.

"Bad decisions are typically made by intelligent people who choose to evade the facts," said Allison, 63, a professor at Wake Forest University's School of Business. "If you have a serious character issue, don't ignore it. If you have a serious long-term concern, don't ignore it even if there are a lot of short-term incentives" to approve the decision.
In 2006, Allison concluded that negative amortization mortgages "would help young people get in trouble down the line when they couldn't afford to pay the loans."
So he turned away from this potentially rich source of profit for the bank, despite pressure from institutional investors and shareholders to do these loans.
Evade At Your Own Risk
Management gurus often urge leaders to heed their gut instincts when pondering a tough decision. Allison agrees that listening to your gut is important, along with confronting facts.

"Don't ignore what you deeply know to be the truth," he said. "I call it the ultimate psychological sin of evasion. It can be easy to rationalize a decision and evade facing facts, especially when there are no short-term consequences."

During Allison's tenure as CEO from 1989 to 2008, BB&T grew from $4.5 billion to $152 billion in assets.In the late 1970s, John Allison was an account manager at regional bank BB&T. Cattle futures rose to a record as ranchers struggle to boost the U.S. herd from a 63-year low, and hogs climbed to a 34-month high after a virus that kills piglets spread, spurring concerns that meat supplies will shrink.

Beef output in the U.S., the world's top producer, will fall 5.3% this year to 24.35 billion pounds (11.04 million metric tons), the lowest since 1994, the Department of Agriculture has forecast. At the start of this year, the cattle herd fell to 87.7 million head, the lowest since 1951, following drought and high feed costs. Porcine epidemic virus has killed more than 4 million pigs, according to an industry group.

This month, the USDA lowered its 2014 forecast for red-meat production and boosted the outlook for cattle and hog costs. Higher meat prices will raise expenses for retailers, while grocery shoppers will pay as much as 3.5% more for meat this year, compared with a 1.2% increase in 2013, the government projects.

Cattle futures for April delivery rose 1.5% to settle at $1.44525 a pound at 1 p.m. on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. After the close, the price reached $1.453, the highest for a most-active contract since the commodity debuted in 1964. Trading almost doubled compared with the 100-day average for this time, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

Hog futures for April settlement climbed 0.4% to $1.01025 a pound. Earlier, the commodity reached $1.0165, the highest since April 21, 2011. The price has gained 24% in the past 12 months.Cattle futures rose to a record as ranchers struggle to boost the U.S. herd from a 63-year low, and hogs climbed to a 34-month high after a virus that kills piglets spread, spurring concerns that meat supplies will shrink.Beef output in the U.S., the world's top producer, will fall 5.3% this year to 24.35 billion pounds (11.04 million metric tons), the lowest since 1994, the Department of Agriculture has forecast. How do you jump-start growth in a 112-year-old motorcycle brand that's been operating in low gear?

Ask Polaris Industries (PII) CEO Scott Wine, and he'll tell you all about it. Wine oversaw the power-sports giant's 2011 buyout of Indian Motorcycle, which suffered from a long history of struggles ranging from changing owners to bankruptcies.

Now, after spending 2-1/2 years re-engineering and overhauling the Indian bikes and their engines, Polaris will reveal the fruits of its labor with the launch of the all-new 2014 Indian Chief heavyweight motorcycle at the 73rd annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally in Sturgis, S.D., Aug. 3.
The redesigned Indian Chief, the flagship of the iconic brand's product line, is powered by Polaris' new Thunder Stroke 111 V-Twin engine. The bike will be available at a starting price of $18,999.
Chasing Harley

Polaris already has a strong position in the motorcycle market with its Victory brand, which is the world's No. 2 seller of the heavyweight motorcycles behind kingpin Harley-Davidson (HOG). By acquiring Indian, Wine saw the opportunity to become a major player in the space, where Victory has a low-single-digit market share.
"We realized that the two brands together would give us a formidable motorcycle business," Wine told IBD in an interview prior to the launch.
He sees the Indian Chief as a product that will rev up Polaris' position in the motorcycle space and help it better compete with Harley-Davidson.

Harley-Davidson, says Wine, is a "formidable competitor" with more than 80% of the market. But it has not had any competition from an "iconic" brand in the industry. That's where the new Indian Chief comes in. Polaris took what it's learned from building the Victory brand from the ground up and applied it to developing the Indian Chief.
"The bike will be fantastic," said Wine. "You have an iconic brand with the most powerful engine going into a heavyweight motorcycle."

Wine wouldn't go into much detail about the new bike pre-launch. But Polaris, which makes all-terrain vehicles (ATVs), snowmobiles and motorcycles, has racked up a strong track record on the product front.
Polaris is the world leader in off-road vehicles with a 40% market share in side-by-side vehicles, says Wine.
"We win with great products, and we will bring a great product to this category," he said.
He says the Indian Chief looks beautiful and rides "incredibly well."

As for the revenue opportunity, over the next three to four years, Polaris could see $500 million to $1 billion in sales between the Indian and Victory brands, with much of that coming from Indian, he says.
Wedbush Securities analyst Rommel Dionisio is upbeat about the prospects for the Indian brand and the Indian Chief.
Polaris, he says, brought to market very "excellent" product design and high-quality motorcycles under the Victory brand.

"They're bringing the technology prowess they've developed over the last several years to new designs they've developed for Indian," he said. "The big opportunity is the launch of the Indian Chief. The marketplace has high expectations for them to make quite a splash with this new entry."
There's strong brand-name recognition with Indian, which has a good reputation among motorcycle enthusiasts and enjoys a cult following.
Polaris, he adds, has a strong record of execution with very "solid performing" motorcycles under the Victory brand.
Meanwhile, Polaris boasts a strong track record with its current lineup. It's been on a long-running winning streak of double-digit sales and profit growth.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the company to stay on the fast track when it reports second-quarter results on Tuesday before the bell. They see earnings rising 13% to $1.11 a share and expect sales to increase 11% to $838.75 million.

Dionisio says he sees the potential "acceleration" in sales in the back half of the year amid major product launches in the third and fourth quarters, including the launch of the Indian Chief, as well as launches of new off-road vehicles.

Wine says that Polaris had a "decent" first quarter and it has guided for a "decent" second quarter. But it's guided for a stronger second half of the year when it will unveil a lineup of new products.
Analysts expect full-year earnings to rise 19% to $5.23 a share. They see a 15% jump in 2014.
But taking on Harley-Davidson will be a challenge.
"Harley is a very entrenched competitor in the marketplace with a loyal global following," said Dionisio.
"The big challenge is to try to take some of the share away from Harley. That remains to be seen."
He says it's possible that within a year of the launch of the Indian Chief, it could very well have a revenue run rate approaching, if not exceeding $100 million annualized.
Wine aims to have 120 to 140 dealers for the Indian Chief by the end of 2013. He says that could grow to 300 to 400 dealers over time.
Shares On A Tear
Polaris' stock has been racing ahead, with its shares currently touching a new all-time high.
Why the run-up in the stock?
The market expects Polaris to launch some major products in the third and fourth quarters — off-road vehicles as well as the Indian Chief, says Dionisio.
Wine says Polaris has several new off-road vehicles coming out this summer.

Polaris has scored big wins with new products, with 73% to 74% of revenue typically coming from products introduced in the last three years, says Wine.How do you jump-start growth in a 112-year-old motorcycle brand that's been operating in low gear?Ask Polaris Industries (PII) CEO Scott Wine, and he'll tell you all about it. Wine oversaw the power-sports giant's 2011 buyout of Indian Motorcycle, which suffered from a long history of struggles ranging from changing owners to bankruptcies.Now, after spending 2-1/2 years re-engineering and overhauling the Indian bikes and their engines, Polaris will reveal the fruits of its labor with the launch of the all-new 2014 Indian Chief heavyweight motorcycle at the 73rd annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally in Sturgis, S.D., Aug. 3.The redesigned Indian Chief, the flagship of the iconic brand's product line, is powered by Polaris' new Thunder Stroke 111 V-Twin engine. The marketplace has high expectations for them to make quite a splash with this new entry."There's strong brand-name recognition with Indian, which has a good reputation among motorcycle enthusiasts and enjoys a cult following.Polaris, he adds, has a strong record of execution with very "solid performing" motorcycles under the Victory brand.Meanwhile, Polaris boasts a strong track record with its current lineup. It's been on a long-running winning streak of double-digit sales and profit growth.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the company to stay on the fast track when it reports second-quarter results on Tuesday before the bell. They see earnings rising 13% to $1.11 a share and expect sales to increase 11% to $838.75 million.Dionisio says he sees the potential "acceleration" in sales in the back half of the year amid major product launches in the third and fourth quarters, including the launch of the Indian Chief, as well as launches of new off-road vehicles.Wine says that Polaris had a "decent" first quarter and it has guided for a "decent" second quarter. But it's guided for a stronger second half of the year when it will unveil a lineup of new products.Analysts expect full-year earnings to rise 19% to $5.23 a share. They see a 15% jump in 2014.But taking on Harley-Davidson will be a challenge."Harley is a very entrenched competitor in the marketplace with a loyal global following," said Dionisio."The big challenge is to try to take some of the share away from Harley. That remains to be seen."He says it's possible that within a year of the launch of the Indian Chief, it could very well have a revenue run rate approaching, if not exceeding $100 million annualized.Wine aims to have 120 to 140 dealers for the Indian Chief by the end of 2013. He says that could grow to 300 to 400 dealers over time.Shares On A TearPolaris' stock has been racing ahead, with its shares currently touching a new all-time high.Why the run-up in the stock?The market expects Polaris to launch some major products in the third and fourth quarters — off-road vehicles as well as the Indian Chief, says Dionisio.Wine says Polaris has several new off-road vehicles coming out this summer.Polaris has scored big wins with new products, with 73% to 74% of revenue typically coming from products introduced in the last three years, says Wine.
If you've ever seen a mountain biker hauling full-tilt over rocks and ruts, or an ATV driver barrel over terrain you wouldn't ride a mule on, you understand the importance of suspension systems.
Without proper suspension, these folks would go flipping head over hindquarters quicker than you can say "X Games."
For the best riders and drivers, not any kind of suspension will do. They spend a lot of money on high-end bikes and vehicles, and expect the best parts and systems in return.
This is the market Fox Factory Holding (FOXF) targets.

Fox Factory designs and makes high-performance suspension products for mountain bikes, snowmobiles, motorcycles and other on- and off-road vehicles. It aims for the high end of the market — bikes and vehicles ridden by racing pros and other serious competitors.
"Most of Fox's customers on the bike side are real avid riders," said Lawrence Solow, an analyst at CJS Securities, which co-managed Fox Factory's Aug. 8 initial public offering on the Nasdaq.
These are not your weekend warriors out to sweat off a few extra calories for a couple of hours.
"About 5% of their customers are professionals, but the others also race or ride competitively," Solow said. "These are customers who always aspire to have the best product."
Fox gets most of its business from original equipment manufacturers. Its key customers include Trek and Cannondale in the mountain bike market, and Ford (F) and Polaris (PII) in powered vehicles.
Big In The Best Bikes

About two-thirds of Fox's revenue come from its mountain bike division. In this segment, Fox offers front fork and rear suspension products. Solow estimates that the company has close to 70% market share in the "high-end," or top quartile, of the 3.5 million suspended mountain bikes sold globally.
"They are taking more share in high-end retail bikes," Solow said. "They dominate that market in terms of suspension."

Fox also has a dominant position in certain powered vehicle categories. The company holds an estimated 75% of the suspension market for side-by-side vehicles, which are ATVs that hold two passengers instead of one.

It also dominates the suspension market for a category known as on-road pickup trucks with off-road capabilities, Solow says. For that, Fox can thank its deal to supply suspension products for Ford's F-150 SVT Raptor, which was introduced in 2010.
Fox's products are sold to around 150 OEMs (original equipment manufacturers) and distributed to more than 2,300 retail dealers. OEM customers account for about 81% of overall revenue.

Most of Fox's competition comes from privately held companies. In mountain bikes, key rivals include Manitou Products, Marzocchi and RockShox. Its main competitors in powered vehicles include KYB, Sachs and Walker Evans Racing.

One of Fox's competitive advantages is its ability to keep coming up with new designs, analysts say. The company was founded in 1974 by Robert Fox, an engineer and motocross rider who designed an "AirShox" system in his garage as a way of improving on the performance of traditional coil springs.
In the years since, Fox Factory has earned a reputation for market-leading designs.

"It has been first to market with numerous innovative new product offerings. In addition, Fox has been able to leverage its expertise to address a broader range of end-markets and a variety of vehicles," Jon Andersen, analyst at William Blair, noted in a Sept. 3 report initiating coverage on Fox Factory.

He points to Fox Factory's success in the premium segment of the all-terrain vehicle category, which "preceded the widespread adoption of Fox suspension technology in the recreational side-by-side market."
Innovating The Ride
In 2012, Fox Factory launched more than 20 new products and got over 70% of its revenue from products introduced over the preceding three years.
Those products include the Podium RC3 for motocross bikes. The RC3 allows riders to make external adjustments so the shock can be tuned for different skill levels, terrain and racing type.
Another product, the ECS shock, boasts an external cooling system that can significantly lower temperatures, which lets powered vehicles operate at higher speeds for extended periods.

New product introductions have helped Fox Factory more than double its annual revenue over the past four years. The company is on track to log nearly $270 million in sales this year, up from $236 million in 2012.
Fox went public with an offering price of 15. It closed its first day of trading at 18.61, a 24% gain. Shares currently trade near 20.

On Sept. 19, the company reported second-quarter results. It posted sales of $70.3 million, up 16% from the prior year. Net income climbed 32% to $5.7 million, while gross margin increased 190 basis points to 29.0%.
In a statement, CEO Larry Enterline said Fox Factory "identified several areas" for future margin improvement, though he didn't name which areas.

Over the past several years, the company has traded margin growth for more manufacturing capacity in order to meet sales demand, analyst Solow says. This increased production has led to "rising inefficiencies," including excess staff, freight and other costs.
While Fox Factory works to improve its efficiency and margins, it also has "multiple pathways for growth," Andersen notes.
He cites growth in existing product categories and market share, expansion into new product categories and geographic markets, and opportunities to move into other price categories.

Fox is the sixth largest firm in IBD's Leisure-Products industry group, after Harley Davidson (HOG), Polaris, Brunswick Corp. (BC), Tumi Holdings (TUMI) and Arctic Cat (ACAT).If you've ever seen a mountain biker hauling full-tilt over rocks and ruts, or an ATV driver barrel over terrain you wouldn't ride a mule on, you understand the importance of suspension systems.Without proper suspension, these folks would go flipping head over hindquarters quicker than you can say "X Games."For the best riders and drivers, not any kind of suspension will do. Polaris (PII), the company that launched the off-road power contest, again staked out high ground this year with its RZR XP 1000. The 107-horsepower, side-by-side trail-gobbler raises the stakes for manufacturers including Arctic Cat (ACAT),…

Tyson Foods (TSN) surged to an all-time high Friday after reporting strong quarterly results and offering a still-bullish sales outlook despite outbreaks of bird and hog viruses. The meat, poultry, pork and prepared food products maker's fiscal first-quarter earnings per share jumped 50% to 72 cents, beating Wall Street's consensus by 9 cents. Tax And Spend: Puerto Rico's debt has been cut to junk by two credit rating agencies, prompting an outcry from officials of the recession-hit island that, after all, they've hiked taxes. Well, that's the problem right there.It's hard to not feel some sympathy for Puerto Rico's new governor, Alejandro Garcia Padilla, who upon entering office last year inherited a hog-wallow of $70 billion in debt, according to a long piece in the weekend's New York Times.The governor cut spending by 2%, balanced his budget a year ahead of schedule, reformed public pensions and reduced the territory's deficit by 70%.It wasn't good enough. Moody's cut the island's credit rating two notches to Ba2 late last week, following Standard & Poor's, which cut the municipal rating to BB+ a few days before that."Unjust," the governor told the Times Sunday. "I've done everything I can to avoid a downgrade," he said.However, to make those numbers add up, he hiked taxes on corporations to 39%, far higher than the U.S. rate and well above the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development average, and let stand a regressive tax on small businesses, giving them a top rate as high as 130%, hitting businesses with the smallest margins, such as groceries, the hardest.That, plus the phaseout in 2006 of an important tax incentive to U.S. corporations to locate operations tax-free on the island, caused the commonwealth's manufacturing job base to plunge from 160,000 to 75,000, a Detroit-like hollowing out in a very short period.Combined with public employee unions controlling the electricity supply, forcing companies in a manufacturing-heavy economy to pay double what companies on the U.S. mainland pay, and an increasingly failed educational system — which has kept the workforce uncompetitive (with 90% not meeting the No Child Left Behind standards nor proficient in English) — it's not hard to see why Puerto Rico has an economic growth deficit, which is the root of all its fiscal ills.This is what Moody's was trying to tell the Puerto Ricans when it cut their debt: "While some economic indicators point to a preliminary stabilization, we do not see evidence of economic growth sufficient to reverse the commonwealth's negative financial trends."Exactly. There's an old rule of thumb that a state can spend all it likes, but should never allow spending growth to exceed its economic growth. Austerity measures alone won't help in a prolonged recession, because the more critical problem to be tackled is government overspending and entrenched special interests, which are both far harder for politicians to deal with than simply taxing the productive to pay for the mistakes of the nonproductive."The new administration has a bookkeeping mentality, as opposed to an economic development mentality," Pedro Pierluisi, the island's non-voting representative to Congress, told the Times.Too much bureaucracy, much of it for welfare, and too much rewarding failure over success drive up costs and drive out the productive. Puerto Rico's most talented citizens are voting with their feet. The island loses about 1% of its population a year, a deadly loss compounded over the years for any economy.To bring these people back, the governor has to fight to cut taxes and really go after the country's entrenched special interests with a baseball bat.The 39% corporate tax has to go.He also must fight in the U.S. Congress to reinstate Puerto Rico's special tax break that ended in 2006 so that investment will once again return.Finally, he must also take on Big Labor's favorite, the Jones Act, which artificially drives up shipping costs, putting local manufacturers at a disadvantage, demanding Congress at least give Puerto Rico an exception.Just balancing the budget on the backs of the productive class won't cut it. The ratings downgrades are a wake-up call to Puerto Rico to fight for real growth — not just a fiscal future a little less like Detroit.
In 1998, Rick Bergman was an executive at tech firm S3. He reported to Terry Holdt, who was returning to run the company after a previous stint as its CEO.

"He came back at a stressful time to take the company back to its glory," recalled Bergman, now president and chief executive of Synaptics (SYNA), which develops human interface tools for electronic devices.

Bergman admired Holdt's diligent efforts to listen and learn. Rather than rush to make sweeping pronouncements, the returning CEO met with both the firm's vice presidents and its directors — one level below VPs — to solicit input and identify key concerns.

"Holdt was very humble," Bergman said. "He felt — and I believe this now — that those at the director level typically stir the drink that directs the company. Directors know what changes need to be made and they can make those changes."
Introvert In Charge
Bergman, 50, joined Synaptics in September 2011 as CEO. The San Jose, Calif.-based company had about 600 employees at the time; its head count has soared to roughly 1,100 today.
At last month's Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Synaptics exhibited its latest touchpad technology and fingerprint authentication solutions for notebook PCs and smartphones.
Unlike CEOs who dominate a room, Bergman's less-showy style pays off. Just as he observed Holdt lead by engaging managers in conversation, Bergman follows suit.
"I'm a little more quiet than many people in my position," he said. "No one would say I'm an extrovert."

He was heartened that Jim Collins, author of the 2001 book "Good to Great," found that CEOs of companies with category-beating success tended toward introversion. Rather than hog the spotlight and seek "hero status," these reserved personalities are often quietly effective leaders.

For many years, Bergman has championed a concept that he calls "O.T.E." or "Opportunity To Excel." He urges employees to pounce on opportunities to showcase their strengths and venture outside their comfort zone for the betterment of the organization as a whole.

"I like to challenge people to grab the ball and run with that O.T.E. to find a way to get things done," Bergman explained. "If an opportunity comes up, I want somebody to carry that ball, not stand pat and let somebody else do it."

About one year ago, Bergman convened staffers to discuss the company's core values. He sought their input on updating the three values of innovating, partnering with customers and offering stimulating work to employees.
"We gathered about 20 employees at a time in focus groups," he said. "Our goal was to look at our core values and tweak them as necessary."

At one meeting, a longtime R&D scientist at the firm, Dave Gillespie, suggested replacing "stimulating" with "exhilarating" to capture the excitement of the workplace environment. Everyone agreed — and the new core value reflects his change.In 1998, Rick Bergman was an executive at tech firm S3. Polaris Industries (PII) delivers fun for adrenaline junkies. For investors, the maker of off-road vehicles, snowmobiles and motorcycles offers growth and income.The Medina, Minn.-based firm has posted top- and bottom-line growth in four of the past five years. Tough economic times in 2009 sent profit down 8% and sales down 20%. But Polaris' earnings and sales have grown by double digits each year since.Polaris' growth has come organically and through acquisitions. Recently, the company made two deals. In April, Polaris bought Aixam Mega — a French maker of small cars and light-duty commercial vehicles. The buyout expands its portfolio of small vehicles and positions it for international growth. Last year, 28% of total sales came from outside of the U.S.In December, Polaris bought Teton Outfitters, which makes Klim motorcycle and snowmobile riding gear.Polaris bought the iconic Indian Motorcycle in 2011 to compete against Harley-Davidson (HOG).In February, Polaris boosted its quarterly dividend by 14% to 42 cents a share. The firm has raised its shareholder dividend for 18 straight years.On an annual basis, the company pays $1.68 a share for a 1.6% yield. Polaris has the second-highest yield among the seven dividend-paying stocks in the Leisure-Products group. Only thinly traded  Escalade (ESCA), which makes pingpong tables and pool tables, has a higher dividend yield.Polaris hit a new high Tuesday, but reversed lower. Despite this, the stock remains extended from a 93.99 buy point in a flat base. The stock initially broke out May 21, but retreated to its 10-week moving average after small gains.
Harley-Davidson (HOG) shares hit a new 52-week high after Citigroup raised its price target to $50 from $46 earlier.
Citi said the largest U.S. motorcycle maker has lean inventory levels and its retail credit availability has remained stable to slightly improved over the last few months.

Harley-Davidson said in January that it has realized cumulative savings of $217 million from a restructuring begun in early 2009, in line with company estimates. The company expects restructuring activities to generate annual ongoing savings of $315 million to $335 million, beginning in 2014.
Its stock price was up more than 2% to 47.91 in strong volume in intraday trading. Shares have climbed more than 50% since a low of 31.50 on Aug. 26, and they've surged 500% since March 2009.

Elsewhere in the leisure products group, all-terrain vehicles maker Polaris Industries (PII) edged up 9 cents to 67.25 midday. Arctic Cat (ACAT), which also makes all-terrain vehicles and specializes in snowmobiles, rose 5 cents to 40.91, and Johnson Outdoors (JOUT), maker of boats and other marine products, was up a dime at 16.20.
On Jan. 24, Harley reported fourth quarter earnings per share of 24 cents, beating analyst estimates by a penny, compared to an 18 cent a share loss in the same quarter a year earlier.
Sales for the quarter rose 9% to 1.18 billion, also topping views.
"In 2011, we made strong progress at transforming our business to be more agile and effective than ever," Chief Executive Keith Wandell said in a statement after the company announced results.
Wandell said Harley has shorter product development lead times, more flexible manufacturing processes and an improved retail experience compared to before the restructuring.

Earlier this month, Harley said it's trying to leverage its stereotype image as in a new ad campaign. The iconic American motorcycle maker has seen a resurgence in recent years in large part because affluent Boomers have bought Harleys for its image as a maker of rugged, fun vehicles.
The new campaign will leverage its new crowd-sourcing Facebook application called Fan Machine.
Fan Machine allows Harley-Davidson's 3.3 million Facebook followers to review an advertising campaign outline, and then offer their own ideas on how the campaign should be run.
The campaign will center on a series of online videos featuring various Harley-Davidson riders and a related stereotype, for example lively grandma or hip student, that shows as a Twitter hashtag.

The ads are designed to start a conversation among Harley riders that could change its advertising and, longer-term, possibly lead to new motorcycle designs.Harley-Davidson (HOG) shares hit a new 52-week high after Citigroup raised its price target to $50 from $46 earlier.Citi said the largest U.S. motorcycle maker has lean inventory levels and its retail credit availability has remained stable to slightly improved over the last few months.Harley-Davidson said in January that it has realized cumulative savings of $217 million from a restructuring begun in early 2009, in line with company estimates. The market has been rocky with bad economic news out of Europe and a weak jobs report in the U.S., but its been a smooth ride for all-terrain and other recreational vehicle makers — as well as gun maker Sturm, Ruger & Co.'s  (RGR), whose stock rose 4.2% to 51.59 as of early afternoon Thursday. ATV maker Polaris (PII)…
Stock futures stumbled onto mixed terrain ahead of Friday's open.

Dow futures were a relatively steady 42.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures kept to a narrow 2.6-point gain. Nasdaq 100 futures backed out of early gains and were down a fraction, possibly hurt by Micron Technology's (MU) 15% premarket slide following a weak fiscal third-quarter report delivered late Thursday.
But it's clear that the stock market today has a lot to chew on.

An accord between the eurozone and Greece appeared to be off the table for Friday, with analysts projecting either a last-ditch deal would be reached over the weekend or all parties would start the week resigned to a Greek default on the $1.8 billion payment owed Tuesday to the International Monetary Fund. Global markets reflected investors positioning themselves for the eventualities.

That pushed Europe's leading indexes to modest losses near midday Friday, but the benchmark indexes in Paris and Frankfurt were still tracking toward gains in the 4% range for the week. The euro edged up against the dollar.

China's mainland markets dug into a serious correction, with the Shanghai Composite diving 7.4% and the tech-heavy Shenzhen Composite down 7.9% on Friday. The markets were hit by liquidity concerns triggered by a wave of IPOs last week, which led to fear that the frothy markets were set to unwind. The second week of steep declines left the indexes down 18.8% and 20.3%, respectively, from their June 13 peaks.
Hong Kong's larger and more internationally exposed Hang Seng Index fell 1.8% Friday, ending the week effectively flat.

In the U.S. markets have remained in their holding pattern this week. The S&P 500 ended Thursday down 0.4% and even with its 50-day line. The Nasdaq is down 0.1%, drifting 1% above its 50-day moving average.
The only real data point on Friday's economic front is the University of Michigan's final June consumer sentiment estimate, due out at 10 a.m. ET.

In stocks, Nike (NKE) muscled up nearly 4% ahead of the open after reporting solid fiscal fourth-quarter results late Thursday. Earnings jumped 25% in a fourth straight double-digit gain. Revenue gained a better-than-expected 5%. Analysts attributed the surprise to tight cost controls. The stock has been in a lilting uptrend, gaining only 1% above a 103.89 buy point after a mid-May breakout.

Athletic shoe retailer Finish Line (FINL) soared 7% after healthy Q1 results. A 7% earnings gain foiled consensus expectations for a 13% decline. A 9% revenue gain also topped expectations. The stock has been in a steady uptrend off a December low, routing out of a nine-month consolidation.

Chipmaker Micron slumped 15% ahead of the open. It reported late Thursday its fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings declined more than expected. The stock has been in a declining correction below a December peak.

Agricultural commodities were in motion Friday as continued rain in the Midwest raised concerns of lost production. Wheat futures jumped 2.5% to $5.51 a bushel and were up $12 for the week. Corn rose more than 1% Friday to $3.88, up nearly 10% over last Friday's settle.

Other commodities were mixed, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate crude oil down, Brent crude up a fraction each. Gold added a few pennies, rising to $1,173 an ounce. For the week, WTI oil and natural gas were essentially unchanged.
