The euro edged up against the dollar.China's mainland markets dug into a serious correction, with the Shanghai Composite diving 7.4% and the tech-heavy Shenzhen Composite down 7.9% on Friday. The markets were hit by liquidity concerns triggered by a wave of IPOs last week, which led to fear that the frothy markets were set to unwind. The second week of steep declines left the indexes down 18.8% and 20.3%, respectively, from their June 13 peaks.Hong Kong's larger and more internationally exposed Hang Seng Index fell 1.8% Friday, ending the week effectively flat.In the U.S. markets have remained in their holding pattern this week. The S&P 500 ended Thursday down 0.4% and even with its 50-day line. The Nasdaq is down 0.1%, drifting 1% above its 50-day moving average.The only real data point on Friday's economic front is the University of Michigan's final June consumer sentiment estimate, due out at 10 a.m. ET.In stocks, Nike (NKE) muscled up nearly 4% ahead of the open after reporting solid fiscal fourth-quarter results late Thursday. Earnings jumped 25% in a fourth straight double-digit gain. Revenue gained a better-than-expected 5%. Analysts attributed the surprise to tight cost controls. The stock has been in a lilting uptrend, gaining only 1% above a 103.89 buy point after a mid-May breakout.Athletic shoe retailer Finish Line (FINL) soared 7% after healthy Q1 results. A 7% earnings gain foiled consensus expectations for a 13% decline. A 9% revenue gain also topped expectations. The stock has been in a steady uptrend off a December low, routing out of a nine-month consolidation.Chipmaker Micron slumped 15% ahead of the open. It reported late Thursday its fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings declined more than expected. The stock has been in a declining correction below a December peak.Agricultural commodities were in motion Friday as continued rain in the Midwest raised concerns of lost production. Wheat futures jumped 2.5% to $5.51 a bushel and were up $12 for the week. Corn rose more than 1% Friday to $3.88, up nearly 10% over last Friday's settle.Other commodities were mixed, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate crude oil down, Brent crude up a fraction each. Gold added a few pennies, rising to $1,173 an ounce. For the week, WTI oil and natural gas were essentially unchanged. Gold was down 2%.

Stocks touched new intraday lows Monday in afternoon trading, then inched above those lows.The Nasdaq slid 0.6%, while the S&P 500 and the NYSE composite fell 0.7% and 0.9%, respectively. Volume picked up from its earlier low trajectory but was still below Friday's pace.Oil, farm machinery and tobacco were among the hardest hit industry groups. Leisure products led on the upside.Recently, more top-rated stocks have been developing repulsive-looking charts — not a good sign for the overall market. Today a couple of more heretofore strong stocks were getting beat up.Cigarette maker Lorillard (LO) gapped down 7% in heavy volume. Only three sessions ago, the stock was only 1% off a 52-week high and 28% above a 89.81 buy point from a March breakout. The stock punctured its 50-day line today and now is 14% off its high.Catalyst Health Solutions (CHSI), a pharmacy benefits management provider, gapped down 5% in heavy volume. The stock lost its 50-day line Friday, and appears to be en route to its fourth straight daily loss. The stock is now 17% off a 52-week high notched in mid-May.On the upside, motorcycle maker Harley-Davidson (HOG) rose 4% in almost twice its usual volume after UBS Investment Research gave it a short-term buy rating. The stock, however, reversed lower from its early 7% gain. Harley-Davidson isn't a top-rated stock. The EPS Rating is 52, which means its earnings growth is about in line with the average stock.

The Leisure-Products industry group is acting very playful. The group is ranked No. 2 among 197 IBD groups, based on six-month price performance, going into Thursday. It has been in the top three for a month, the top five for two months. And its performance relative to the broad market has improved during the recent market turmoil. Group leaders are…
Kathy Ireland was featured in the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue for 13 straight years.
When she appeared on the cover in 1989, it became the best-selling issue of all time.
Finally, at age 30, she figured she would segue to another career with longer-lasting legs.
That moment came in 1993. While modeling some foot warmers, she liked them so much that she decided to make them the first product of her lifestyle design.
Thus started kiWW — short for kathy ireland Worldwide — with Ireland and her physician husband borrowing $50,000 to launch it.
"Everyone laughed at us and said, 'You can't start a brand with socks — why don't you create a swimsuit?'" Ireland told IBD. "They slammed doors in our faces."
Since then, kiWW has sold over 100 million pairs and expanded to 60,000 stock-keeping units in everything from furniture and luggage to wigs and greeting cards.
Last year, Forbes estimated that privately held kiWW drove retail sales of $1.5 billion and that Ireland, its CEO and chief designer, earned $10 million.
California Girl
Born 48 years ago in Glendale, Calif., Ireland was 3 when she moved with her family to Santa Barbara, where she's lived ever since.
At 4, she was selling painted rocks out of her wagon.

At 11, she had a paper route and was confronted by a man who told her it was a "boy's job and you're never going to last." Several times she wanted to quit, but she wouldn't give him the satisfaction.
Her dad taught her to "always give 110%, more than what's expected," she said. Result? Carrier of the Year three times.
In 1980, at 17, Ireland was discovered by Elite Model Management and was featured in the 1984 SI Swimsuit Issue, landing on the cover in 1989, 1992 and 1994.

Ireland says her modeling career gave her (1) solid experience with top designers, (2) travel exposure to other cultures' needs, sparking inspiration for themes when she started designing her own products and (3) a tutorial in rejection. "I was told all day I was too short, too fat, that my hair was wrong, that I wasn't smart enough," she recalled. "It toughened me."
Her pet peeve was being told to "shut up and pose." It motivated her to get into a position where she could make the decisions.

Ireland saw that the fashion business was built around airbrushed fantasies. She vowed that when she built her own company, it "would have nothing to do with how someone else perceived how I looked, and the products would be for the real needs of people."

Irv Blumkin, president of Nebraska Furniture Mart, a Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) company, said that "many celebrity brands in our industry are just endorsements, famous people just putting their name on a product line, while Kathy is a gifted designer because she understands the needs of American families. She's the real deal."

More praise comes from Stephen Roseberry, kiWW's president, who said Ireland has "rejected tens of millions of dollars in business to grow it right and get it right. If she can't be involved in every step of the process of product development, she walks away because integrity is at the core of everything she does."
Holding Firm
Roseberry, who has worked with Ireland for 20 years, gave an example from a few years ago when a manufacturing partner was dragging its heels on meeting California environmental standards.

"They wanted to just not sell in California, but Kathy told them, 'Our family lives in this state and we're not going to sell merchandise elsewhere that would not be legal in our own home,'" he said. "The manufacturer and bankers went wild, but she said 'No.' She's gentle and tough. Her faith is the foundation of her success and there's a scripture that applies to her: 'Be as meek as a lamb and sharp as a serpent's tooth.'"
Before she started kiWW, Ireland tried to branch out from modeling with other projects.

She developed a line of cosmetics, but wasn't satisfied with the formulas or the people she worked with. Then she helped start a microbrewery, before realizing she didn't have a passion for beer. And real estate investments failed.

The right ride was kiWW. It rocketed in its first decade, boosted largely by a Kmart-Ireland clothing line. In 1999, Ireland was named Businesswoman of the Year by the National Association of Women Business Owners.
Trouble came in 2002, when Kmart filed for bankruptcy.

"It was an avalanche of harsh reality," Ireland said. "My banker asked me out to lunch and I thought it was for a routine update. But he had this chilling smile when he told me, 'You know that you and your partners are personally liable, and if this doesn't work out, we can take away your homes.'"
More Markets

Ireland refused to desert Kmart in its time of crisis, but realized she could no longer be so dependent on one outlet. After the big-box store folded into Sears Holdings (SHLD), she changed kiWW's distribution strategy, moving to specialty stores.
Today a wide variety of retailers — 50,000 stores in 29 countries — carry kiWW products.

"Independent retailers and those who supply them are what will turn this country around," Ireland said. "It's exciting to see their entrepreneurial spirit and innovation, reaching out of their comfort zone to grow stronger during these challenging times."

Ireland said that in seeking new outlets, "I learned from Warren Buffett, when we worked with him on our carpet line, that you need to find retailers who can deliver a great customer-service experience. We worked 24/7 to build up those relationships one at a time."
Ireland's primary target customer is the busy mom — someone she understands, since she often rises at 4:30 a.m. to juggle work while caring for her three daughters.

"By the time a mom arrives at a store, she's put her kids in their car seats, given them juice, calmed a temper tantrum and changed a diaper," she said. "The last thing she needs is to go into a huge store where she is overwhelmed with choices, and the sales associates don't know the products. Sales is the lifeblood of every business, and I love working behind the scenes to get advice from the sales team and share our knowledge. We want everyone to know the story behind each product."
Ireland stays in touch with customers through focus groups and the 50,000 who follow her tweets.
She says that although it's a generality, there is truth to the saying that "men buy products, but women join brands."

"A well-branded product will outperform a generic because trust simplifies the selection process," Ireland added. "We enjoy success because we've worked so hard to maintain trust, not rely on yesterday's success. The best way to destroy a brand is to provide a poor price-to-value ratio."

With her suite of bridal products and services, from event locations to jewelry, Ireland said that "if we get the most important day of her life right, we've likely earned her trust in other areas for a lifelong relationship."
One result: The trade magazine License Global last year ranked kiWW 28th among top brand licensors, ahead of icons like Martha Stewart, Harley-Davidson (HOG) and Coca-Cola (KO).

From quality control to distribution, Ireland admits to "being a control freak," even though she cedes technical expertise to her 37 employees. "I barely graduated high school, so I'll sketch a basic design and leave it to someone with a master's in fine arts to work out the details," she said.
Globe-Trotter
When she isn't working at home, she's commuting to offices in Los Angeles, Palm Springs, New Jersey, Hawaii and Israel. She loves to make surprise factory inspections.

Last year kiWW partnered to launch a number of new lines, including one with Window World, the nation's largest replacement window company, and another with LaJobi, a leading maker of furniture for children.

As if all that weren't enough, she has written half a dozen best-selling books, including "Real Solutions for Busy Moms" in 2009, and competed in the fall 2009 season of TV's "Dancing With the Stars."

Looking back on all the rejection throughout her career and the near-fatal business crises, Ireland is dancing all the way to the bank.Kathy Ireland was featured in the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue for 13 straight years.When she appeared on the cover in 1989, it became the best-selling issue of all time.Finally, at age 30, she figured she would segue to another career with longer-lasting legs.That moment came in 1993. This year a number of companies initiated dividends, including True Religion Apparel (TRLG), Apple (AAPL) and GameStop (GME). Some investors see the initiation of a dividend as a sign a company has become too old to maintain fast growth. But maybe that reaction is what has become dated. "In the late 1990s, when tech stocks were the hottest thing, nobody…

Top workers don't just hustle. They shine in the eyes of superiors and peers. How soft skills draw applause: • Walk the tightrope. "The world demands perfection, yet it craves authenticity. No one can be perfect and authentic at the same time." So says Connie Dieken, author of "Become the Real Deal." How to be brilliantly human? "Forget perfection and…
Stocks opened strongly and finished that way Tuesday, thanks to a round of positive earnings reports.
The NYSE composite climbed 1% while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 gained 0.8% each. The Dow lag with a 0.2% gain. Declines in IBM (IBM) and Coca-Cola (KO) weighed on the blue chip index.
Volume fell across the board.

Atheros Communications (ATHR) gapped up and rallied 8% on more than twice its average trade. Late Monday, the chipmaker beat views with an 850% pop in Q1 earnings. And it guided second-quarter profit well above consensus estimates. The stock has gained 13% since clearing a 37.93 buy point from a cup-with-handle base March 2.
Aixtron (AIXG) gapped up and climbed 5% in heavy trading. The German firm makes equipment that makes LEDs. It reported triple-digit profit growth in the latest two quarters.
BJ's Restaurants (BJRI) added 3% to a record high. The stock extended its win streak to seven sessions.

On the downside, Goldman Sachs (GS) reversed an early gain and lost 2%. The U.K.'s Financial Services Authority launched an investigation into alleged fraud charges. That news offset strong Q1 results from the bank.

In after-hours news, Apple (AAPL) delivered fiscal Q2 earnings and sales that blew past views. It guided fiscal Q1 profit ahead of analysts' estimates, but the firm pegged sales below views. Still, shares jumped 5% in extended trading.
Altera (ALTR) jumped 9% in extended trading after reporting Q1 results above views. It gave a rosy sales forecast for the current quarter.
Cree (CREE) also posted quarterly results above views and gave a strong outlook for the current quarter. But it slipped 2% in extended trading.
Hard drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) gained 3% after it delivered fiscal Q3 earnings and sales above views.
Panera Bread (PNRA) reported Q1 earnings ahead of analysts' estimates and raised its full-year guidance. The operator of bakery-cafes was supposed to report April 27.

Earnings Wednesday: Altria (MO), Boeing (BA), Chipotle (CMG), Citrix Systems (CTXS), EMC (EMC), F5 Networks (FFIV), Freeport-McMoRan (FCX), McDonald's (MCD), Mellanox Technologies (MLNX), Morgan Stanley (MS), Netflix (NFLX), NetGear (NTGR), Qualcomm (QCOM), SanDisk (SNDK), Starbucks (SBUX), United Technologies(UTX) and Wells Fargo (WFC).
U.S. Stocks Close Higher; Nasdaq Retakes 2500
BY VINCENT MAO
Earnings optimism sent stocks higher Tuesday.

The NYSE composite climbed 1% and the Dow 0.2%. The S&P 500 rose 0.8%, closing back above the 1200 level. The Nasdaq gained 0.1%. It finished a tick above 2500. Volume fell across the board. Advancers beat decliners by more than 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq and about 4-to-1 on the NYSE.

Energy-related industry groups were Tuesday's top performers, thanks to a jump in crude oil. May crude rose $2 to $83.45 a barrel. Transportation-related groups were some of Tuesday's worst performers.
Stocks Hold Gains Ahead Of Key Earnings
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks were again holding near highs ahead of earnings releases from some leaders after the close.
The NYSE composite was up 0.9%, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 rose 0.8% each. The Dow climbed 0.3%.
Volume was again tracking lower on both exchanges.

Apple (AAPL) slipped 1% ahead of its fiscal Q2 results after the close. Analysts see the tech icon's earnings climbing 84% to $2.45 a share on sales of $12.04 billion. Apple is up 14% since clearing a 215.69 buy point from a cup base March 5.
Chipmakers Altera (ALTR) and Cree (CREE) each climbed 3% ahead of their quarterly results after the close.
Seagate Technology (STX), VMware (VMW) and Yahoo (YHOO) also report earnings after the bell.

Elsewhere, Bottomline Technologies (EPAY) rallied 6% in heavy trade. It cleared a 17.84 buy point from a handle. The payment processor reports earnings Thursday. Views are for 23 cents a share, up 53%.
U.S. Stocks Remain Near Intraday Highs
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks continued to hold near session highs with a couple of hours left in Tuesday's session.
The NYSE composite gained 0.9%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the Dow 0.4%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq rose 0.7%. It eased after rising past the 2500 level.
Turnover continued to track lower across the board.

Imax (IMAX) gapped up and climbed 6% to just near its April 6 peak. The stock cleared a 14.70 buy point from a cup base March 8. Late Monday, the entertainment technology firm said it signed a new theater deal in Japan. Imax has benefited from box-office hits such as "Avatar" and "Alice in Wonderland" shown on its 3-D screens. The company's full-year earnings are slated to leap 722% to 74 cents a share this year.

NetGear (NTGR) ran up 5% to a two-year high in fast trade. It staged an upside reversal near its 50-day moving average Monday. The networking gear maker reports earnings after the close Wednesday. Analysts see profit surging 650% to 30 cents a share.
U.S. Stocks Hold Near Highs
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks hovered near their intraday highs in early afternoon trading Tuesday. Equities have been fueled by a barrage of strong earnings reports since the open.

The NYSE composite rose 1%, boosted by gains in energy issues. Crude oil rose $1.94 to $83.39 a barrel. The S&P 500 climbed back above the 1200 level, adding 0.8%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq also rose 0.8% to just below the 2500 mark. The Dow picked up 0.4%. Volume was tracking lower across the board.

EZCorp (EZPW) climbed 7% to a record high in fast trade. The operator of pawnshops and payday loan centers reports fiscal Q2 results Thursday after the close. Its earnings are slated to rise 16% to 43 cents a share.

New Oriental Education & Technology Group (EDU) gapped up, rising 6% to a record high. Before the open, the school operator smashed views with a 26% rise in fiscal Q3 earnings. Sales grew 36%, also above views. New Oriental sits 11% past a 88.60 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) rose 3% as it bounced back from a three-session pullback. The stock cleared a 30.33 buy point from a base-on-base pattern April 14. The skin care and nutritional products maker reports earnings before the market's open April 28. Analysts see profit rising 50% to 42 cents a share.

Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) rose 2% after falling in the past three sessions. It cleared a 32.33 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern March 23. Late Monday, group mate IBM (IBM) reported Q1 results above views, signaling acceleration in the IT sector's recovery. Cognizant reports its quarterly earnings May 4. Analysts see profit rising 17% to 48 cents a share.
U.S. Stocks Hit Intraday Highs At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes continued to trade broadly higher in mixed volume at midday Tuesday.
The NYSE composite rose 0.9%, the S&P 500 0.7%, the Nasdaq 0.6% and the Dow 0.3%. Volume remained mixed. It fell 5% on the NYSE and rose 6% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Monday.
CNinsure (CISG) vaulted 7% in twice its normal trade. The China-based property and casualty insurance company's stock is rallying after finding support above its 50-day moving average on Monday.
EZCorp (EZPW) rose 4% in three times its usual turnover. The pawnshop chain and payday loan provider notched an all-time high.

Priceline.com (PCLN) gained 3% in above-average volume. The discount travel services provider sports accelerating quarterly sales and earnings growth and highest-possible ratings for IBD Composite and Earnings Per Share ratings.

Auto sales were surprising strong early this year. But potholes at home and major cracks in Europe could send automakers into a skid.

Automakers will post U.S. July sales throughout the day tomorrow. Another clue to the health of the industry comes Thursday when the world's No. 1 automaker, General Motors (GM), posted full second-quarter results.
For GM earnings, analysts forecast 74 cents per share, down 52% from a year ago. Revenue is seen slipping 2% to $38.58 billion.

GM, which retook the global top automaker spot from Toyota Motor (TM) in the first half, previously said it had record sales in China in the first six months of the year, up 11.3% from a year ago. But growth there has been slowing, causing headaches and concern for many large U.S. multinationals.
Europe is also a major trouble spot. Ford Motor (F) last week doubled its forecasts for full-year losses in Europe to more than $1 billion. GM too has had trouble in its European Opel division.
It's shaken up its management team there, and on Sunday axed its global marketing chief.
Shares, which have trickled lower through the quarter, were up 1.1% to 9.20 in early-afternoon trading Tuesday.

For total industrywide U.S. sales, automotive information firm J.D. Power and Associates forecasts a July seasonally adjusted annualized rate of 14.1 million vehicles, roughly on par with June. Sales last year totaled 12.8 million units.

Penske Automotive Group (PAG), which owns one of the largest groups of U.S. dealerships, said vehicle unit sales surged 21% in Q2. New-car sales were up almost 25%, with used-car sales climbing 16.4%.
That drove net revenue up 19.2% to $3.37 billion, beating views. Earnings climbed 25.6% to 54 cents, matching analysts' consensus estimate.
Also Tuesday, parts maker TRW Automotive Holdings (TRW) posted better-than-expected Q2 earnings Tuesday but bumped its 2012 outlook down slightly on worries about auto sales in Europe.

There's a bumper crop of corn this year, which is driving down feed costs. That's good news for poultry producer Pilgrim's Pride (PPC).
But not just yet.

Wesley Batista, chief executive of Brazil's JBS SA, the world's largest meat producer and parent of Pilgrim's Pride, the No. 2 U.S. chicken producer after Tyson Foods (TSN), said Thursday that he expects profit margins from its poultry division to improve in the fourth quarter on lower feed costs.
But Pilgrim's Pride is locked into feed contracts at higher prices that will continue until fall. So Pilgrim's Pride shares plunged more than 11% Thursday to 16.49 on Batista's comments.

Still, demand for chicken is "solid-to-excellent," Pilgrim's Pride CEO William Lovette said Aug. 1 in an earnings call with analysts. Export demand is growing, Lovette added, "and the export outlook is favorable into 2014."

Pilgrim's Pride shares climbed 3% in midday trading in the stock market today, Friday. Prior to Thursday's plunge, its stock had risen 307% from an Oct. 25 low of 4.57 to a multiyear high 18.58 close on Wednesday.

Among other poultry producers, Tyson, which is up about 16% so far this month, was up fractionally Friday afternoon. Sanderson Farms (SAFM) and Brazil-based BRFS SA (BRFS), which produces specialty meats including chicken, beef and pork products, both fell about 1%.

In news about other related food companies, egg producer Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) fell. Hog producer Smithfield Foods (SFD), whose proposed $4.7 billion takeover by a Chinese company has sparked debate, was also down a bit.There's a bumper crop of corn this year, which is driving down feed costs. It must be August in these United States. How else to explain all the ridiculous high dudgeon over the rodeo clown at the Missouri State Fair wearing an Obama mask?

OMG, someone mocking the arrogant Oval Office guy, as late-night comedians do most weekdays now. (Leno: Obama out on his 'Middle Class Jobs & Opportunity Tour.' Don’t confuse that with his first term 'Jobs & Missed Opportunities Tour.')

C’mon, America. This is the country that began with a Revolution, thumbing its nose at a monarch for George’s sake. It’s humorous here when someone makes fun of authority figures. Every president for decades has had his face turned into a grotesque Halloween mask. Or worse.

Ever go to an NHL game when they introduce the commissioner? The boos are so loud you’d think he was Harry Reid. Or remember 2008 and the raunchy, disgusting abuse heaped on Sarah Palin and, to a lesser extent, Hillary Clinton?
The job of rodeo clowns is to distract the angry bull after he’s dumped the rider. And the clowns entertain the human crowd in between bull riders’ getting dumped by the angry bull.
One standard rodeo clown routine is to drag into the arena a scarecrow dummy that, holy smokes, suddenly comes alive because it’s actually a real person. Haha
Back in 1994, the the Examiner reminds us, one rodeo clown got a grand crowd response when a bull tore to shreds a scarecrow wearing a George H.W. Bush mask. The nation survived.

Saturday night in Sedalia before a not-even-close-to-sellout crowd one of the clowns showed up on the arena floor wearing a face mask of Obama, who was going to unite us all, remember? An announcer asked if anyone wanted to see the bull run over the president? And, predictably, the crowd went wild, hooting and laughing.

See, it’s funny because that clown wasn’t really Barack Obama. The real Barack Obama was vacationing on Martha’s Vineyard (see above), clowning around for the camera on a golf green, mocking drum majors or Americans not occupying a $7 million island estate. Who knows? Maybe he had a few of his homemade beers.

The last time Obama was in a rodeo arena was 2007 when he wore good shoes and actually set up his teleprompter in the dirt and other debris. The real Barack Obama was never in any danger Saturday night and everyone watching the clown skit in Missouri knew that. Hence, they were free to laugh at the clowns.
Now, admittedly, the brief rodeo skit wasn’t as entertaining as that episode of HBO’s “Game of Thrones” last year that featured the severed head of President George W. Bush on a stake.
Apparently wearing a live mic, the Obama clown opined, “Hey, I know I’m a clown. He’s just running around acting like one. Doesn’t know he is one.”
“Watch out for that bull, Obama!” said the arena announcer.

But state fair officials were not laughing. And they don’t see it as free speech. No siree, Bubba. They were furious. They issued a written statement calling the act “inappropriate” and an “unconscionable stunt.”
They’re pondering action against the Missouri Rodeo Cowboy Assn., the event’s contractor. They have now ordered that all clowns undergo future sensitivity training for something.
And -- get this -- the fair banned the unidentified Obama clown from working the fair for life.
That might delight both of msnbc's viewers, but it seems rather overkill. Certainly worse punishment than the Dixie Chicks endured for their overseas tirade against Bush II.
Truth be told, anyone who’s spent a hot, humid August afternoon at a state fair in hog country might just appreciate such a ban.
Gov. Jay Nixon was so distressed that he held a news conference to surf the media fervor.
You won’t be surprised to learn that the unsmiling pol is a Democrat. He wasn’t at the rodeo, of course. But he didn’t like what he’d heard about what happened where he wasn’t, saying:
“The performance was inappropriate and offensive and does not reflect the values of Missourians." Which obviously do not include a sense of humor for these folks.
Good thing Don Rickles wasn’t performing over at the fair amphitheater.
RELATED:The tough questions no one asks Obama
Obama 'is so out of touch with unemployed Americans'
Classic Obama charade: Appoint a crony to investigate himself

Stocks charged ahead for the best percentage gain in the Nasdaq since April 10. The Nasdaq popped 1.6%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average added 1.4% and 1.1%, respectively. The IBD 50 pushed 1.5% higher. Volume rose across the board. Thursday's action constituted a follow-through day. This confirms that the market is in an uptrend. Fundamentally…

Leading leisure stocks have been hard at work. Several of their industry subgroups are among the leaders of IBD's 197 groups.Buying by mutual funds is one of the key drivers.The Leisure-Products group ranks No. 2. That's up from No. 4 eight weeks ago. Leisure-Travel Booking ranks No. 3, way up from No. 111 eight weeks ago.At the 20th spot, Leisure-Services is well up from the 64th spot it occupied two months ago.Fun StocksLeaders of Leisure-Products include Harley-Davidson (HOG), Polaris (PII),  Brunswick (BC) and Sturm Ruger (RGR).Fidelity funds such as $3.1 billion Advisor Equity Growth and $1.1 billion Growth Discovery added to their stakes in Harley-Davidson as of their latest disclosures.Priceline.com (PCLN) is the 800pound gorilla of Leisure-Travel Booking. Typifying fund industry interest, $30 billion T. Rowe Price Growth Stock increased its position.And Hertz Global (HTZ) is a key driver in the Leisure-Services group.The $1.1 billion Alger Capital Appreciation bought more shares in its latest disclosure.Why are leisure names thriving?Despite worries by some investors, U.S. GDP is growing and consumer spending is up, says Patrick Dunkerley, lead manager of $1.2 billion Scout Mid Cap Fund .And Priceline, for one, is gaining share even in its European base as travelers shift to online booking, says Turner Investments' Christopher Baggini, manager of $24 million Titan and co-manager of $947 million Spectrum funds.Serious Fun"By culture, Europeans don't shelf vacation travel even when the economy slows," he said. "They may trim spending, but they don't eliminate it." Hotels' average daily room rates have risen for two years.In addition, Priceline's Asian arm, Agoda, continues to grow.Baggini also likes Intercontinental (IHG) and Starwood (HOT) in the leisure-lodging group. "Both have stories for Asian growth, which continues to grow nicely," he said.Coinstar (CSTR), in the Leisure-Movies & Related group, is up 44% this year.The firm got 85% of its revenue last year from its Redbox movie and video game kiosks, where consumers can rent or buy.It also runs self-service coin counting kiosks.Coinstar's gains are largely due to competitor Blockbuster's collapse and Netflix's (NFLX) pricing missteps, Baggini says. "After this rally, I would hold off (on buying more Coinstar)," he said.He continues to like Priceline, Intercontinental and Starwood going forward.Room For VroomHarley-Davidson makes motorcycles, parts, clothing, accessories and collectibles.It suffered seven quarters of falling earnings-per-share during the downturn years of 2008-09.Since then EPS have climbed nine quarters in a row as sales rose 2% and 9% the past two years.Demand is expected to keep rising for at least the near term in the U.S. and Europe, says S&P Capital IQ analyst Efraim Levy.Motorcycles' smaller price tags and operating costs vs. cars appeal to consumers who are wary of economic prospects.This helps draw in new buyers, Levy adds.

Hormel Foods (HRL) shares fell sharply early Tuesday in heavy volume after the meat producer cut its full-year profit outlook, citing weakness in its pork business and rising costs.

The warning comes amid broad changes in the industry as rival Smithfield Foods (SFD), the world's largest pork products producer, ponders a bid for the company by a Chinese company and considers appeals from investors to split up the company.

Hormel now sees full-year earnings per share for the fiscal year ending in October of $1.88 to $1.96, down from $1.93 to $2.02 earlier. The revised guidance is well below Wall Street's target of $1.99 a share.

"We remain very bullish about our future earnings potential," CEO Jeffrey Ettinger said in a statement, adding, "We will provide more details regarding the outlook during our Investor Day on June 26."
Hormel shares were down 4.6% in midday trading on the stock market today.
Among other large U.S. meat producers, Smithfield edged up fractionally, Tyson Foods (TSN) rose 1%, Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) 0.5% and Sanderson Farms (SAFM) retreated 1.5%.
Following three quarters of double-digit profit growth early last year, Hormel's profits have weakened.

In the last three quarters, earnings growth per share fell from 14% to 0% and 2% last quarter. Prior to Hormel's earnings guidance cut, consensus of nine analysts polled by Thomson Reuters was a 17% hike in EPS this quarter.

Hormel shares climbed 52% from an Oct. 24 low of 28.45 to an all-time high of 43.17 on May 15 before turning down amid signs of sector weakness in the Food-Meat Products group, which is still ranked a strong 21 on IBD's list of 197 industries.
Smithfield earlier this year warned it expected lower profit in 2013 on falling pork prices.
On Monday, Smithfield was for the second time this year urged by a large shareholder to split the company up before selling it.
Activist shareholder Starboard Value said there was more equity in the company than was reflected in a $34 per share offer — about $7.1 billion including debt — by China's Shuanghui International.

Starboard urged Smithfield to split into hog production, pork and international businesses and sell them separately. That echoed a statement from shareholder Continental Grain earlier this year. Makers of big boy-toys were being hammered Tuesday. So too sellers of pricey yoga clothing and lip gloss.

A consumer discretionary stocks sell-off swept across industries and demographics. And there could be more of that to come as No. 2 package shipping company FedEx (FDX) forecasted a stalling global economy.
Polaris Industries (PII), which makes all-terrain vehicles and motorcycles, was out 4% to 81.45. Harley Davidson (HOG) 2.4% to 45.21. Snowmobile and ATV maker Arctic Cat (ACAT) fell 6.4% to 40.99.
But it wasn't just male-dominated consumer stocks that retreated.
Salon chain and beauty products retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA) fell 2.3% to 97.40.
Canadian yoga and fitness clothier Lululemon Athletica (LULU) was down 3.8% to 74.49. Athletic clothing rivals Under Armour (UA) and Nike (NKE) were down slightly too.
Shoe maker Deckers Outdoors (DECK), owner of the Ugg Boots and other brands, fell 8.8% to 43.76.

Even purveyors of luxury goods — a bright spot in the retail landscape — weren't spared Tuesday. Fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) was down 3.1% to 52.28. Leather handbags and accessories seller Coach (COH) fell 3.4% 59.98.

The pull back for consumer discretionaries follows a run-up for many of them, after generally stronger Q2 earnings. About 67% of consumer discretionary stocks in the S&P 500 beat views for profits last quarter, according to data from Thomson Reuters. But most — 71% — missed on revenue.Makers of big boy-toys were being hammered Tuesday. Any baseball player who makes the Hall of Fame does so because of talent and sweat.
Some also rely on adaptability.
Few ballplayers exemplify that more than Dave Winfield.
"I was always willing to listen, learn and apply something new," Winfield, 59, told IBD. "Had I not been willing to make any adjustments, I would have been a different footnote in baseball history."

Early in his major league career, Winfield used a long, heavy bat, making it tough to catch up to pitchers' blazing fastballs. What to do? He noticed that the day's top hitters, namely Joe Morgan and Tony Perez, used lighter bats.

"I experimented and finally settled on a 34-ounce, 35.5-inch bat, aware that as I got older and lost some strength or quickness I might have to go to any even shorter, lighter bat," he wrote in "Winfield: A Player's Life."
It was one of many shifts that resulted in a 22-year career with six teams: the San Diego Padres, New York Yankees, California Angels, Toronto Blue Jays, Minnesota Twins and Cleveland Indians.
Big Numbers
When Winfield was done after the 1995 season, he stood as a rare player to produce at least 3,000 hits (3,110) and 400 homers (465).
He qualified for 12 straight All-Star games, grabbed seven Golden Gloves for his outfield play and was a champion, helping Toronto to a triumph in the 1992 World Series.

Growing up in Minneapolis, Winfield caught on to baseball with Bill Peterson. The local playground supervisor taught Dave and other kids how to play the sport and suited up some for an American Legion squad. "Bill was an ex-Marine, although you're never really an ex-Marine," said Steve Winfield, Dave's older brother. "He pushed the fundamentals of the game and emphasized repetition and more repetition. When I was 12 and Dave was 11, we were hotshots on the Pee Wee team. Bill took one look at us and said, 'Wait until I get you next year.'"

Peterson tolerated no nonsense or excuses from his players, and always pushed them to work hard. Thanks in part to that direction, Winfield starred at the University of Minnesota in baseball and basketball — and made the dean's list.

Winfield's athletic prowess was so impressive, four pro teams — baseball's Padres, the National Basketball Association's Atlanta Hawks, American Basketball Association's Utah Stars and National Football League's Minnesota Vikings — drafted him in 1973.
He went with San Diego.

"I chose the one where I felt I had the most fun and the most success, and that was baseball," he said. "I liked a lot of the little things about it, like every time I was up at bat, I loved the challenge. I liked hitting the ball hard. I played good defense and I had a good (throwing) arm. It was all working for me, all of the tools and skills."
Not to mention his brain power.

"It's very easy to forget he's one of the best athletes ever because when you talk to him that rarely comes up," said Mario Casciano, a long-time Winfield friend who also handles his public relations. "When he was going to Yankee Stadium every day, he would carry at least one, usually two, attache cases. He was always reading."
When Winfield leapt from college to major league ball in the middle of the '73 season, he saw quickly how many players had it over him.
He also caught on to what made them better: consistency, their ability to excel every day.
Time for Winfield at adjust.

"I knew that to develop that, to maximize my abilities, would mean I'd really have to work on the fundamentals — the right way to hit, field, run and think — and to incorporate them into a style that took into account my personal strengths, quirks and weaknesses as a player," Winfield wrote.
On The Board

He needed top traits to get his first major league hit. In the ninth inning of his first game, he bashed the ball to the left side, where Houston third baseman Doug Rader dived and knocked down the ball.
Needing a hit "like a hog needs slop," as Winfield wrote in his book, he charged to first base and slid head-first into the bag, beating Rader's throw.
"It taught me that I have to work very hard and go all-out and see where that takes me," Winfield said. "I never took anything for granted."

That surfaced the next year in spring training, with Winfield fighting for a roster spot and pinch-hitting in the ninth inning against Cleveland. He responded by smacking a double and — after a teammate's hit — running through the third base coach's stop sign.

"I think, 'Hell, no! I've got a team to make,'" Winfield wrote. "The catcher is straddling the base path, the ball's on its way to his glove, but the way I see it I'm destined to score. I slam into the catcher, he drops the ball, the game's over, we win. And I'm a Padre."
Late in his career, at age 37, Winfield suffered a back injury that required surgery, costing him the entire 1989 season.
Again, his adaptability kicked in.
"After that year off, I made adjustments on where I placed my hands on the bat and how I moved by body to enable me to hit at a high level," he said.

Winfield played well enough in 1990 to be voted Comeback Player of the Year. By 1992 he had landed in Toronto, where at age 40 he had a stellar year. His .290 batting average, 26 home runs and 108 runs batted in helped propel the Blue Jays to their first world title.

Reflecting on his career, Winfield said, "Baseball is a game, it's a science and it's a business. I think understanding all of those things helped me have a lengthy, successful career. It wasn't just physical ability."Any baseball player who makes the Hall of Fame does so because of talent and sweat.Some also rely on adaptability.Few ballplayers exemplify that more than Dave Winfield."I was always willing to listen, learn and apply something new," Winfield, 59, told IBD. "Had I not been willing to make any adjustments, I would have been a different footnote in baseball history."Early in his major league career, Winfield used a long, heavy bat, making it tough to catch up to pitchers' blazing fastballs. Jobs, co-founder and chairman of Apple, was known to introduce big surprises at the end of media events by announcing he had "one more thing" to show the crowd. As CEO of Apple,…
SAN FRANCISCO — Ever since Apple's (AAPL) iPhone went on sale in 2007, Verizon Wireless customers have held out hope that, one day, AT&T's (T) grip as its exclusive U.S. distributor would be broken.
That day arrives Feb. 10, when Verizon's iPhone goes on sale. Verizon started accepting preorders from existing customers on Thursday.

It's the same Apple phone as AT&T sells, with a few small tweaks. The price is the same: $200 or $300, depending on how much memory you want. Verizon wants your signature on a two-year contract, just like AT&T.
But even if it's the same phone, Verizon does things differently from AT&T, so there are some important factors to consider if you're thinking about getting one.
Speedier Videos

The big difference is likely to be network performance. AT&T's network is notoriously congested in some cities, including San Francisco, where for a week I tested both phones side by side. Out in the country, Verizon has wider coverage for broadband wireless data.

The Verizon model was generally speedier at loading maps, websites and videos. For example, I was already done watching a YouTube clip of an adorable sneezing baby panda on Verizon's phone when AT&T's finally gave up on loading the video. At times, I couldn't make a call on the AT&T iPhone but could easily do so on Verizon's.

So Verizon was faster for me, but the situation could be the opposite in many places across the country. Where AT&T's network isn't congested, it's actually faster than Verizon's, at least where AT&T has made recent upgrades.
There are two other big changes.

Verizon's iPhone is the first to work on so-called CDMA networks, the type used by Verizon, a joint venture of Verizon Communications (VZ) and the U.K.'s Vodafone (VOD). AT&T uses GSM, a technology that's more widely used around the world. This means the Verizon iPhone has very limited international roaming abilities. It won't work at all in Europe, for instance.

Verizon's iPhone also includes Personal Hotspot, a Wi-Fi sharing feature that is becoming increasingly common on smart phones. It lets you connect as many as five gadgets to the Internet through the iPhone. If you're stuck without an Internet connection for your laptop, for instance, you connect through the phone and Verizon's network.

The feature is easy to use, but there's a price for this convenience: $20 per month on top of what customers already pay for voice and data services. With voice, text and data plans, that could mean monthly bills topping $110.
By contrast, AT&T lets you use the iPhone to surf on the Web on a single computer — and only by connecting the two with a USB cable or through Bluetooth. This, too, costs an extra $20 per month.
Another thing to consider about Verizon's iPhone: If you're a data hog, or think you might want to be one, you might be drawn to Verizon's data plan, which allows for unlimited use.

AT&T got rid of unlimited-data plans for new customers last year. Most users get by with the two gigabytes of data allotted through its $25-per-month plan, which is $5 cheaper than Verizon's unlimited plan. But if you go over the monthly allotment you'll shell out for more data — $10 automatically for every gigabyte or fraction of it over.
Lock-In Data Plan
If unlimited data is a must, sign up now, because Verizon has said it will switch to limited-data plans sometime this year.

By getting an iPhone now, you can lock in the unlimited plan for at least two years. Another thing about Verizon's iPhone: You won't be able you use data services while making a phone call. That means that if you're chatting with your grandmother about her upcoming birthday, you can't put your grandma on speakerphone while ordering her a bouquet of tulips online. Nor can you look for new games in Apple's iTunes App Store while jumping into that conference call for work.
It's annoying, though not a deal breaker, for me at least. And if you can connect to Wi-Fi, you will be able to use that to get online while talking on the phone.

One more consideration: It's likely a new iPhone model will be out this summer, and it's not clear whether Verizon will get it right away. If weighing the pros and cons get to be too much, just remember that whether you buy it now or hold out for the next iteration, you're still getting an iPhone, silly.

Cattle futures fell the most in seven weeks on speculation that U.S. grocers may have filled meat orders for the Memorial Day holiday. Hogs also dropped.

Meatpackers processed 606,000 head of cattle in the first five days of this week, down 1.8% from the same period in 2012, U.S. Department of Agriculture data show.Retailers may have finished their meat purchases for the Memorial Day holiday weekend that starts May 25, according to broker Allendale Inc.Memorial Day is the second-most-popular day for grilling, according to the Hearth, Patio & Barbecue Association. The Independence Day holiday on July 4 is No. 1."We have some concerns about demand as we go into next week and beyond," said Rich Nelson, the chief strategist at Allendale in McHenry, Ill.."The first week of May is when we do Memorial Day buying. Typically after this week, that's when we have a letdown" in demand, he said.Cattle futures for June delivery declined 1.5% to settle at $1.21825 a pound at 1 p.m. on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, marking the biggest slump for the most-active contract since March 15.Feeder-cattle futures for August settlement slid 1.4% to $1.475 a pound.Hog futures for June settlement fell 0.7% to close at 92.175 cents a pound on the CME. Prices are up 7.5% this year.

Tyson Foods (TSN) reported first-quarter profit above estimates Friday. The effects of last summer's drought are expected to weigh on chicken and beef production in 2013. But football fans don't need to worry, there will be plenty of chicken wings for the Super Bowl, according to the National Chicken Council.
The chicken, beef and pork producer said Q1 EPS climbed 14% to 48 cents, beating Wall Street analyst estimates of 6 cents. Sales rose 2% to $8.4 billion, but fell short of estimates for $8.6 billion.
Shares were up nearly 3% in midday trading Friday.

Tyson's outlook for 2013 is cloudy. The company is expecting total domestic protein production to decline 1% from 2012 levels. The drought the past summer reduced grain supplies boosting feed costs for cattle and hog producers.

The USDA expects chicken production to be flat during the year. But consumers have been worried about chicken shortages after the National Chicken Council announced a 1% decline in chicken production over 2012.

Super Bowl weekend accounts for nearly 5% of annual consumption of chicken wings, but fans getting ready for Sunday's game shouldn't be concerned with the report. The council said it's not worried about "any shortage of wings on Super Bowl Sunday or any time soon."
The Food-Meat Products group is ranked No. 45 out of Investor's Business Daily's 197 industry groups.

Tyson leads the group with a Composite Rating of 94. IBD's Composite Rating rates stocks in five areas, with extra weight on earnings and stock price strength. A 94 rating means the company is in the top 6% of all stocks covered.
